docs.lead_paragraph: A few days ago, two well-spoken executives from the computer security concern Symantec came by the office to complain about Microsoft. Lots of software companies have complaints about Microsoft, of course, but it's not every day that one of them embarks on a multicity media tour to voice them. That got my attention. They wanted to talk about Microsoft's new operating system, Vista, which the company plans to begin shipping soon to computer manufacturers, and will introduce it over the next several months. It is the first big upgrade of Windows in five years, and it's a pretty big deal. ''Vista is important for the acceleration of growth for Microsoft,'' said Rick Sherlund of Goldman Sachs, the pre-eminent Wall Street analyst covering the company. ''It's also important that they solidify the security of the operating system.''

headline.main: Feeling Free To Take Shots At an Old Bully

docs.abstract: Joe Nocera Talking Business column on computer security company Symantec's attempts at discouraging customers from switching to Microsoft Corp's upcoming new Vista software program; says Vista lacks antivirus protection; speculates that Microsoft did not include antivirus protection because it felt that such software needed to remain province of computer security industry, which generates billion in revenue selling such software; adds that to make it part of Vista would be viewed, especially in Europe, as being too harmful to industry; holds fact that Microsoft is competitor in security arena is why computer security companies view Vista with such fear (M)
docs.snippet: Computer security firms are complaining that a feature in Microsoft’s new operating system would cripple their industry’s innovation.

docs.lead_paragraph: YouTube, the popular video-sharing Web site that has yet to celebrate its first anniversary or its first profit, is quickly becoming the must-have prize for media and technology giants. Google is in discussions to acquire YouTube for $1.6 billion, people involved in the talks said yesterday. While the talks are in the early stages, and may fall apart, the size of Google's offer may push YouTube closer to a deal. Other companies have also expressed interest and could swoop in with a higher offer.

headline.main: Google Is Said To Set Sights On YouTube

docs.abstract: Google is in discussion to acquire YouTube, popular video-sharing Web site, for $1.6 billion; Microsoft, Yahoo, Viacom and News Corp, among others, have visited YouTube's headquarters in San Mateo, Calif, in recent months to inquire about buying company; deal for YouTube would be crowning moment for property that emerged as cultural phenomenon almost immediately after it officially began last Dec; its site delivers over 100 million video clips a day; Chad Hurley, founder of company, says he prefers to stay independent; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Google is said to be in discussions to acquire the popular video-sharing Web site that has yet to turn a profit, for $1.6 billion.

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Starbucks agreed to introduce a coffee liqueur with Jim Beam last year, Pax World Funds had no choice but to sell its $23 million Starbucks stake. Pax World says it engages in socially responsible investing, and its rules have barred investments in companies that derive revenue from liquor. So Pax World divested, even though it has long considered Starbucks strong on social responsibility and the Jim Beam deal was small potatoes for the coffee chain. But last month, shareholders in two funds, Pax World Growth and Pax World High-Yield, decided that it was time for the company to shed its zero-tolerance policy on alcohol and gambling. At the behest of Pax World's management, they approved more flexible guidelines that will allow fund managers to drop those traditional strict ''sin screens'' and place greater emphasis on corporate governance, climate change and other contemporary issues. The same changes were put before shareholders of the larger Pax World Balanced fund, but its balloting was extended to Oct. 26.

headline.main: The Give and Take of 'Socially Responsible'

docs.abstract: Mutual Funds Report; mutual fund managers who say they are devoted to socially responsible investing are finding themselves bending some rules, including dropping some traditional strict 'sin screens' to get better returns; many are placing greater emphasis on corporate governance, climate change and other contemporary issues; Pax World Growth and Pax World High-Yield decided last month to drop its zero-tolerance policy on alcohol and gambling; interest has been growing in funds that describe themselves as socially responsible; Social Investment Forum says assets in socially screened mutual funds and other pooled products reached $179 billion in 2005, up from $12 billion in 1995; photo (L)
docs.snippet: Steering clear of alcohol and gambling is no longer a snap decision.

docs.lead_paragraph: The political spectacle of the past week has been the gaggle of Republican officeholders and would-be officeholders rushing to return money to disgraced congressman Mark Foley. They are scurrying to divest themselves of Foley stock. I use the term "divest" because it is the term universities use when they decide to withdraw from investments too closely tied to suspect nations or give back funds from a source they consider tainted. Divesting from this or that is fast becoming the newest form of moral posturing and is almost always, I think, a bad idea.

docs.lead_paragraph: FINAL WRAP-UP The Mets swept the Dodgers, which given the state of their starting pitching before the series began was probably something that nobody could have predicted. The one thing that was clear from the series is that the Mets have a very, very good bullpen. Now they fly back to New York to await the winner of the St. Louis-San Diego series. After how they handled the Dodgers, the Mets should feel reasonably confident going into that series.Thanks to everyone who logged in to watch the blog. And thanks particularly to Ray Krueger for moderating the blog and sending me some of the comments from readers. This is Dylan McClain signing off. Go Amazins!!

docs.lead_paragraph: On a whiteboard in a windowless Microsoft conference room here, an elegant curve drawn by a software-testing engineer captures both five years of frustration and more recent progress. The principle behind the curve -- that 80 percent of the consequences come from 20 percent of the causes -- is rooted in a 19th-century observation about the distribution of wealth. But it also illustrates the challenge for the builders of the next generation of Windows and Office, the world's largest-selling software packages.

headline.main: A Challenge for Exterminators

docs.snippet: The five-year redesign of Microsoft Windows and Office has come down to a final scramble to get the programs to users by the end of the year.

docs.lead_paragraph: It took more than 10 minutes to persuade the Paris police station's highest-ranking officer that a crime might have taken place, but that did not deter Jérôme Martinez and his two companions. After all, the three had marched halfway across the Latin Quarter one evening in late September, accompanied by about 40 fellow advocates, waving banners and handing out parking-ticket-style leaflets that claimed they had committed a number of offenses.

headline.main: Their Crime: Playing iTunes On Devices Not Named iPod

docs.lead_paragraph: HERE is a look back at some of the highlights, lowlights and sidelights at the 96th annual conference of the Association of National Advertisers, which almost 1,000 people attended here last Thursday through Sunday. WHY SPY -- When Gary Elliott, vice president for brand management at Hewlett-Packard, began his speech on Saturday, the anticipation was palpable. Would he or would he not address the corporate espionage case that is roiling his company?

headline.main: Tattoos to Massages: It's All About Selling

docs.abstract: Advertising column looks at highlights of 96th annual conference of Association of National Advertisers; Hewlett-Packard vice president for brand management Gary Elliott begins speech by commenting on corporate espionage scandal, saying he does not yet know impact on company's reputation; Gene Simmons of rock band Kiss appears at dinner as principal in Simmons Abramson Marketing; Kaplan Thaler Group chief executive Linda Kaplan Thaler jokes that Wal-Mart will someday merge with United States; senior vice president for marketing at Wal-Mart jokes that it will be China instead; amount of sponsors at conference grows each year along with attendance; contributions help defray cost of meetings; IdeaCast, which operates television network in health clubs, holds drawing for 2006 Mini Cooper convertible with estimated value of $20,000; marketing and production agency Tattoo Projects sponsors makeshift tattoo parlor; Eric Hadley, general manager of Microsoft Digital Advertising Solutions unit of Microsoft, tattoos his right foot; most clients gave agency partners credit during speeches, most likely due to unusually heavy agency attendance; ESPN sponsors Friday dinner, which celebrated Monday Night Football; Home Depot, major theme of conference is need for marketers to embrace blogosphere; Home Depot, National Football League and Schwab all bring employees to conference to write blogs of daily sessions; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A look back at the 96th annual conference of the Association of National Advertisers in Orlando, Fla.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE NEW TV SEASON -- Three weeks into the new network television season, three new shows are giving early signs of being winners: ''Heroes'' on NBC, ''Jericho'' on CBS and ''Ugly Betty'' on ABC. And some scheduling moves have worked brilliantly, like ABC's shift of ''Grey's Anatomy,'' now television's hottest show'' to Thursday night. But on the down side for the networks, several new shows have already been dropped from schedules and many new series have wasted huge audiences from the hit shows that preceded them. [Page C1.] A WARNING FOR STUDIOS -- Warner's recent tumble in the studio rankings is a cautionary tale for Hollywood. As the studios begin to shrink their slates and make fewer movies, they are increasing their reliance on the big, expensive extravaganzas. Sometimes they succeed, as ''Batman Begins'' and the ''Harry Potter'' movies have for Warner. But the lackluster results for Warner's blockbusters this summer show that the large tentpole features are not sure things, after all. And when they fail, they put more pressure on smaller films to open big. [C1.] GUIDING NEW CONSUMERS -- Marketers of all sorts are being urged to give up the steering wheel to a new breed of consumers who want more control over the ways products are peddled to them. Exhortations to bring consumers into the tent dominated an advertising industry conference. Stuart Elliott, Advertising. [C8.] CONNECTING FAMILIES -- Genealogy sites have long helped their customers reconnect with long-dead ancestors. Now, in keeping with the social networking trend, some sites are trying to connect the living as well. Tim Sullivan, MyFamily's chief executive, left, said that changes at Ancestry.com, had spurred interaction between close and distant relatives by letting them more freely share information about their forebears and post old photos. Bob Tedeschi. E-Commerce Report. [C9.] A SHIFT AT MICROSOFT -- At Microsoft, the effort to overhaul the Windows operating system was meant to offer a transformation to a new software foundation. But several ambitious initiatives failed to materialize in time, and the project started over from scratch three years ago. The result is more an evolutionary shift, focusing on visual modernization and ease of use. Still, the company is within a month of completing work on new versions of both Windows and Office. [C1.] OPEC PRODUCTION CUTS -- A consensus among OPEC members began to form over the weekend about cuts in oil production to help stem the recent decline in price, but members have not yet agreed on how to share the reduced output. [C2.] BROADER DIRECTORY SEARCHES -- Tellme Networks and Cingular Wireless are planning an enhanced 411 information service that will use Tellme's voice recognition technology to begin offering some Internet-style searches in addition to telephone directory information. The new Cingular service will permit subscribers to ask questions for a broader set of queries than traditional directory lookup. Information can be delivered as text-to-speech or as a simple text message delivered to the cellphone. [C8.] NEW BOOK, LOST JOB -- On Tuesday, Joe Maguire, one of two editors in charge of markets coverage at Reuters, handed his bosses the galleys of his new book, ''Brainless: The Lies and Lunacy of Ann Coulter.'' On Wednesday, Mr. Maguire discovered he would have plenty of free time to promote his book, which comes out this week. Neither side in this dispute would say that he was fired. ''There was a difference of opinion about the approval I received to write this book,'' Mr. Maguire said. [C6.] QUESTIONS ABOUT POLICY MEETING -- In his new book, ''State of Denial,'' Bob Woodward revealed the presence of journalists, including Fareed Zakaria, the editor of Newsweek International, left, at an otherwise secret meeting Nov. 29, 2001 to discuss Afghanistan and the Middle East in the aftermath of 9/11. The meeting, which included policy makers, Middle East experts and members of influential policy research organizations, was convened by Paul D. Wolfowitz, then the deputy secretary of defense, in an effort to produce a report for President Bush and his cabinet outlining a strategy for the region. Media Talk. [C6.] TROUBLES AT AIRBUS -- Discussions over who will ultimately make decisions regarding the revamping at Airbus continued over the weekend, and executives close to the talks said Sunday that the chief executive, Christian Streiff, could resign as early as Monday if he did not secure the autonomy that he wanted. [C1.] SALE OF BANK STAKE -- Istithmar PJSC, an investment company owned by Dubai's ruling Maktoum family, has acquired a stake of about $1 billion in the London bank Standard Chartered as it seeks to diversify income beyond oil in the United Arab Emirates. [C8.]

docs.lead_paragraph: Google has made it a point to promote a culture of small engineering teams given free time to create new products -- a strategy that it has argued will make the company more innovative than other top-down organizations. But beginning well before its initial public offering in 2004, Google has not shied away from buying rather than building. It has made more than 15 major acquisitions in areas as diverse as blogging, personalized search, satellite imagery, image management and cellular phone technology.

headline.main: Adding On to the House of Google

docs.abstract: Google has made more than 15 major acquisitions in areas as diverse as blogging, personalized search, satellite imagery, image management and cellular phone technology; Google's leaders may be confusing users by piecing together rapidly multiplying set of products; founders Sergey Brin and Larry Page and chairman-chief executive Eric E Schmidt spoke last week of their concern that growing collection is confusing users; they noted that new products found one level down from Google's famously Spartan home page drew far less attention and traffic than they would like; Google's acquisition of YouTube presented difficult choice: intergrate YouTube into Google and risk losing one of hottest brands on Internet, or leave YouTube independent and risk diluting its own powerful brand; Google says YouTube will remain independent for now, retaining 'distinct brand identity' and complementing its own existing video business; chart; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Having pieced together a rapidly multiplying set of products, Google’s leaders have a new concern. Call it Google sprawl.

docs.lead_paragraph: Tellme Networks and Cingular Wireless are planning an enhanced 411 information service that will use Tellme's voice recognition technology to begin offering some Internet-style searches in addition to telephone directory information. Tellme, based in Mountain View, Calif., a major provider of automated directory service to cellphone carriers, finds itself in an increasingly crucial position as both cell carriers and Web portals like Google, Microsoft and Yahoo start to explore the lucrative market for mobile search.

headline.main: Tellme and Cingular Plan Broader Directory Service

docs.lead_paragraph: Robert Scoble, a technology executive, was on a flight from Northern California to Seattle when he found himself seated next to a vice president for Costco. Mr. Scoble, who was then working at Microsoft, was intrigued by how Costco, the giant discount retailer, managed its tech inventory. He struck up a conversation, and by the time he landed had received a master class in big-box retailing. ''I've had more than my fair share of interesting encounters on planes,'' said Mr. Scoble, now a vice president of the start-up Podtech.net and author of a blogging guide, who flies at least once a week on business.

headline.main: Itineraries; Close Encounters of the Flying Kind

docs.abstract: Business travelers find fellow passengers on airplanes can be potential clients or may offer sound advice that will help them be successful; technology executive Robert Scoble discusses sitting next to Costco vice president on recent flight; frequent fliers say odds of finding compatible seatmates vary according to route; tips of airplane conversation etiquette are given; photo (M)
docs.snippet: In the business world of flying, there's a chance your seatmate could be a fascinating entrepreneur.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Cingular 3125, better known in phone-geek circles as the Star Trek because of its similarity to the communicators on the Starship Enterprise, is a full-featured smartphone in a cellphone's body. The four-ounce 3125 is the first clamshell-style phone to run Windows Mobile 5.0 for Smartphones and features a 1.3-megapixel camera. While it does not have a full keyboard, it can be used to send e-mail, browse the Internet and listen to music. It also has Bluetooth wireless networking and a Micro SD memory expansion slot.

headline.main: A Diminutive Cellphone With Signs of Intelligence

docs.lead_paragraph: The government of Libya reached an agreement on Tuesday with One Laptop Per Child, a nonprofit United States group developing an inexpensive, educational laptop computer, with the goal of supplying machines to all 1.2 million Libyan schoolchildren by June 2008. The project, which is intended to supply computers broadly to children in developing nations, was conceived in 2005 by a computer researcher at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Nicholas Negroponte. His goal is to design a wireless-connected laptop that will cost about $100 after the machines go into mass production next year.

docs.lead_paragraph: The investment firm owned by Paul G. Allen, the co-founder of Microsoft, said Wednesday that it had exercised an option to force DreamWorks Animation to sell shares in the company to the public in a secondary offering. Some analysts estimate the offering will be valued around $300 million. That is $200 million -- or 40 percent -- less than the $500 million secondary offering DreamWorks canceled last year after the company missed its projections on DVD sales. Then the stock price tumbled, and Mr. Allen told DreamWorks executives that he planned to revisit the idea of an offering.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Lovely song, isn't it?'' That was Rod Stewart, onstage at the Nokia Theater on Monday night. And he wasn't being immodest: he had just sung ''Father and Son,'' by the singer-songwriter formerly known as Cat Stevens, and he was giving credit where it was due. This was a concert only a C.P.A. could love. The site was a former movie theater operated by the live-entertainment company AEG Live and named for a cellphone company. The occasion was the release of ''Still the Same Great Rock Classics of Our Time,'' an album of covers by Mr. Stewart, on J Records, a subsidiary of Sony BMG.

docs.lead_paragraph: One of India's largest outsourcing companies, Infosys Technologies, announced a 53 percent climb in its quarterly profit on Wednesday, surpassing market expectations and reflecting a strong demand for technology and back-office services from Western customers. [The company, which is publicly traded, also said Wednesday that it planned a large international stock offering of sponsored American depository receipts worth nearly $1.5 billion, Bloomberg News reported.]

headline.main: Profit Rises 53% at Infosys, a Top Indian Outsourcing Company

docs.abstract: Infosys Technologies reports 53 percent climb in quarterly profit, reflecting strong demand for technology and back-office services; quarterly profit rose 9.29 billion rupees ($203.7 million) from 6.06 billion rupees last year; revenue grew more than 50 percent, to 34.5 billion rupees ($756.6 million) chief executive Nandan M Nilekani comments (M)
docs.snippet: Profit at Infosys surpassed expectations and reflected a strong demand for technology and services from Western customers.

docs.lead_paragraph: TRYING TO MAKE IT THERE -- The discount retailer Kohl's, which is run out of Menomonee Falls, Wis., is about to do something that a growing number of budget chains in the Midwest and South have done already: open an office in New York, a symbol of excess that is squarely at odds with its frugal corporate culture and tight-fisted customers. [Page A1.] YOUTUBE FOUNDER'S JACKPOT -- Jawed Karim -- who hit an Internet jackpot in 2002 when PayPal, the online payment company he had joined early on, was bought by eBay -- hit the equivalent of the PowerBall this week when YouTube, which he helped to found, agreed to be bought by Google for $1.65 billion. [C1.] CELEBRITIES FLOCK TO TV ADS -- Advertising agencies say they are finding more, and better, choices among celebrities for their television ad campaigns, as television spots are increasingly seen as a good promotional vehicle for other projects. Advertising. [C1.] LOTT CRITICIZES INSURERS -- Senator Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi and one of thousands of homeowners on the Gulf Coast who have been fighting with their insurers over payments for damage in Hurricane Katrina, said he was angry about the insurers' ''insensitivity and outright meanness'' in rejecting many homeowners' claims. [C1.] RELUCTANCE TO LOWER RATES -- Despite indications that inflation pressures may be starting to ease, the Federal Reserve is not inclined to lower short-term interest rates anytime soon, minutes from its most recent meeting show. [C1.] BUSINESS LEADERS AND SPITZER -- In the race for governor of New York, some business leaders, rather than viewing Eliot Spitzer's battles with Wall Street as noble or civic minded, see a gigantic, calculating ego run amok. Mr. Spitzer is unapologetic, saying the way to strengthen business is by keeping it honest. [A1.] SECOND DREAMWORKS OFFERING -- The investment firm owned by Paul G. Allen, below, the co-founder of Microsoft, said it had exercised an option to force DreamWorks Animation to sell part of his stake in the company to the public in a secondary offering. Some analysts estimate the offering will be valued at about $300 million, 40 percent less than the $500 million secondary offering DreamWorks canceled last year. [C5.] DOUBTS OVER CHINA EXPANSION -- China's Communist Party, devoted in recent years to expanding the economy at any cost, endorsed a new doctrine that puts more emphasis on tackling the severe side effects of unrestrained growth. [A10.] KICKBACK INQUIRY IN ILLINOIS -- Allegations of corruption grew closer to Gov. Rod Blagojevich of Illinois, as a grand jury indicted one of Mr. Blagojevich's advisers and fund-raisers in a suspected kickback scheme involving pension funds. [A20.] MONSANTO LOSS WIDENS -- Monsanto said that its quarterly loss widened as lower sales of seeds and related products offset higher sales of Roundup and other herbicides. Monsanto also forecast profit for 2007 that was below what Wall Street expected, and its shares fell 5.3 percent. [C8.] SOUNDING ALARM OVER STENTS -- More than 2,000 patients are dying needlessly each year from the use of stents, the tiny metal devices that prop open heart arteries, according to an editorial by a leading medical society. [A22.] CHIEFS RESIGN OVER OPTIONS -- McAfee and CNet Networks both said that their chief executives had resigned, as casualties from investigations of stock option grants continue to mount. [C3.] GANNETT MISSES ESTIMATES -- Gannett reported a lower quarterly profit and missed revenue forecasts because of weak advertising. Its shares fell 2.6 percent, to $56.23. [C5.] BLUE CHIPS FALL -- Blue-chip stocks fell for the first time in three days after Alcoa began the quarterly earnings season by missing estimates and Federal Reserve meeting minutes dampened speculation that interest rates would begin dropping. [C6.] FUNDS FOR GREEN BUSINESS -- Venture capitalists continue to see green in the business of finding cleaner and more environmentally friendly energy sources. The latest example is Amyris Biotechnologies, which has secured $20 million. [C7.] INFOSYS PROFIT CLIMBS -- One of India's largest outsourcing companies, Infosys Technologies, announced a 53 percent climb in its quarterly profit, surpassing market expectations and reflecting a strong demand for technology and back-office services from Western customers. [C7.] BELLSOUTH PURCHASE APPROVED -- The Justice Department approved AT&T's purchase of BellSouth without imposing concessions on the companies, angering consumers and raising the odds that the Federal Communications Commission will delay voting on the deal. [C8.] CHANGES FOR BELL CANADA -- BCE, formerly one of the largest holding companies in Canada, said it would dissolve and turn its Bell Canada telecommunications unit into Canada's largest income trust. docs.lead_paragraph: As Google whips out its fat wallet to buy the video site YouTube, it is making Yahoo look even more out of step with the fast-changing Internet advertising market. Yahoo itself tried to buy YouTube just a few weeks ago and got as close as negotiating price and terms, according to an executive briefed on the discussions. But the talks broke down, and Google swooped in and closed the deal quickly, just as it has in several recent partnership negotiations. Indeed, many Internet executives are noting just how often Yahoo appears to be late and slow, both in its own business and in negotiations with other companies.

headline.main: Yahoo Feels Breath on Neck; These Days, No. 1 Portal Seems to Be a Step Behind

docs.abstract: Yahoo is most popular Internet brand in US with nearly 106 million unique visitors in September; its overall growth was just 6.5 percent last year, and number of people using some of its services is down; Yahoo has suffered some embarrassing setbacks in recent months in its sales of display and Web search advertising; many ad industry executives say Yahoo's lead in working with big marketers has eroded as other companies have built up popular Web sites, sales operations and advertising technology; advertising clients are reducing share of their budgets they allocate to Yahoo in favor of newer sites, like MySpace, and sites developed by big media companies like Viacom; Google is taking advantage of Yahoo's problems to cement crucial deals that could make its rival's recovery even more difficult; current and former Yahoo employees say company has been bogged down by bureaucracy and internal squabbling; graph; chart; photo of Yahoo chief executive Terry S Semel (L)
docs.snippet: In recent months Yahoo has suffered some embarrassing setbacks in its sales of both display and Web search advertising.

docs.lead_paragraph: Steven A. Ballmer, the chief executive of Microsoft, has his hands full. The next version of the Windows operating system, Vista, is finally about to arrive -- years late and clouded by doubts that it might violate antitrust rules in Europe. Mr. Ballmer, 50, has been deeply involved in the discussions with the European competition authorities.

headline.main: Is Windows Near End Of Its Run?

docs.abstract: Excerpts from interview with Microsoft chief executive Steven A Ballmer on Microsoft, his job and future of software; next version of Windows operating system, Vista, is finally about to arrive, years later and clouded by doubts that it might violate antitrust rules in Europe; analysts say Windows Vista and Office 2007 may be last time Microsoft can cash in on lucrative personal computer products, as software is increasingly distributed, developed and used on Internet; Microsoft announces that Vista will be shipped in late January and expresses confidence that it will pass regulatory scrutiny; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Steven A. Ballmer, the chief executive of Microsoft, answered questions about the new Windows Vista operating system, his job and the future of software.

docs.lead_paragraph: Microsoft announced Friday that Windows Vista, the next version of its computer operating system, had been altered to satisfy regulatory concerns and would be introduced simultaneously worldwide. Less than a month ago, it had warned that antitrust problems could delay the introduction in Europe and South Korea. A delay in one country or region would have serious consequences for software developers, computer manufacturers and retailers there. It would also create complications for Microsoft, which has always rolled out previous versions of Windows simultaneously around the world.

headline.main: Microsoft Makes Changes in Windows Vista to Suit Foreign Regulators

docs.abstract: Microsoft says Windows Vista, next version of its computer operating system, has been altered to satisfy regulatory concerns and will be introduced simultaneously worldwide; was warned less than month ago that antitrust problems could delay introduction in Europe and South Korea; new operating system will go on sale to large computer manufacturers in November and to public in January (M)
docs.snippet: Microsoft said its Windows Vista operating system had been altered to satisfy regulatory concerns and would be introduced simultaneously worldwide.

docs.lead_paragraph: I.B.M. has moved its global procurement headquarters to southern China from the suburbs of New York City to ''capitalize on emerging market opportunities.'' I.B.M., based in Armonk, N.Y., spends 30 percent of its $40 billion annual procurement in Asia, the company said in a statement yesterday, confirming the move to Shenzhen that was first announced to suppliers in May. This is the first time that I.B.M., the world's biggest computer services company, has moved the headquarters of one of its largest divisions to China.

docs.lead_paragraph: By approving the merger between AT&T and BellSouth unconditionally, the Bush administration has again abdicated responsibility for protecting consumers when huge companies combine. Fierce competition between private companies is at the core of the nation's economic strength. But government still has an important role to play as referee, making sure that the rough-and-tumble game of capitalism doesn't become perversely uncompetitive through significant concentrations of market power in the hands of a few companies.

headline.main: A Growing Free-for-All

docs.abstract: Editorial says by approving AT&T and BellSouth merger unconditionally, Bush administration has again relinquished responsibility for protecting consumers when huge companies combine; urges Federal Communications Commission to consider merger seriously and not wield rubber stamp
docs.snippet: The Bush administration has again abdicated responsibility for protecting consumers when huge companies combine.

docs.lead_paragraph: Some companies trying to attract M.B.A. students have been playing a version of beat the clock: offering bonuses that decline in value or disappear unless the student accepts the job by a certain date. Think of it as early admissions in the corporate recruitment world. The declining bonuses are a tactic this year largely in the finance and consulting industries, although other companies are using it as well.

headline.main: Clock Ticks, Bonus Slips For Recruits

docs.abstract: Some companies trying to attract MBA students have been playing version of beat the clock: offering bonuses that decline in value or disappear unless student accepts job by certain date; declining bonuses are tactic this year largely in finance and consulting industries, although other companies are using it as well; bonuses offered by most promising summer interns, as much as $45,000 in some cases, will be cut in half or will be withdrawn if students do not accept job offers by early deadline, typically middle of October (M)
docs.snippet: More companies hoping to attract M.B.A. students are offering bonuses that decline or disappear unless the student accepts the job early.

docs.lead_paragraph: Wedge Oldham, a 49-year-old software engineer from Los Angeles, finds nothing sweeter than spending a fall weekend in the Black Rock desert, barking rocket launching commands like ''Are we good to go?'' into the hot dusty wind. Nerves jangling, he awaits the moment when Carpe Diem, his homemade 18-foot-long rocket, hurls itself heavenward with 737 pounds of thrust, shockwaves -- or ''mach diamonds'' -- surging from its supersonic exhaust. With dazed exuberance he watches it recede into deep blue sky, and then, with the release of parachutes, gently drift four miles away, preserved for another flight.

headline.main: A Cult of Backyard Rocketeers Keeps the Solid Fuel Burning

docs.abstract: About 100 members of Tripoli Rocketry Assn meet in Black Rock, Nev, desert for Indy 500 of rocketry; highlight of annual event is launching of rockets that teams have spent up to year making at cost of thousands of dollars; amateur rocketeers, about 6,000 nationwide, have had to contend with tougher restrictions from federal government and local fire marshals since Sept 11, and are involved in seven-year-old dispute with Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives over their use of propellant; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Once a year, on a bleak, 400-square-mile dry lake bed, do-it-yourself rocket enthusiasts meet for the Indy 500 of rocketry.

docs.lead_paragraph: China is planning to adopt a new law that seeks to crack down on sweatshops and protect workers' rights by giving labor unions real power for the first time since it introduced market forces in the 1980's. The move, which underscores the government's growing concern about the widening income gap and threats of social unrest, is setting off a battle with American and other foreign corporations that have lobbied against it by hinting that they may build fewer factories here.

headline.main: China Drafts Law to Empower Unions and End Labor Abuse

docs.abstract: China seeks to protect workers' rights by cracking down on sweatshops and giving labor unions real power for first time since it introduced market forces in 1980's; proposed new rules set off battle with American and other foreign corporations that are lobbying against them by hinting they may build fewer factories in China; new law underscores government's growing concern about widening income gap and threats of social unrest, severe side effects of country's remarkable growth; new restrictions, which may go into effect as early as next May, would apply to all companies in China, but its emphasis is on foreign-owned companies and suppliers to those companies; many advantages of locating in China would remain, even with new restrictions and higher costs; some of world's big companies fear new rules would borrow too heavily from labor laws in union-friendly countries like France and Germany; but workers' advocates say new rules are long overdue; they accuse American businesses of favoring system that has led to widespread labor abuse; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Foreign corporations have hinted that they may build fewer factories in China if the law is adopted.

docs.lead_paragraph: To big-name marketers, the teeming mosh pits of social networking sites look like dangerous places for their precious brands. MySpace: Isn't that full of dirty old men picking up teenage girls? Facebook: That's where college students post pictures of bawdy frat parties. And YouTube: Pirated videos -- and people making fun of our commercials. But now these sites and dozens of smaller ones have something those marketers want: the attention of tens of millions of young people who increasingly avoid television commercials. So companies from Procter & Gamble to J. P. Morgan Chase, like so many lonely teenagers, are tricking out their online profiles and trying to make friends on the Web.

headline.main: Joining the Party, Eager to Make Friends

docs.abstract: Advertisers begin to see benefit of social networking sites that attract millions of young people who increasingly avoid television commercials; large companies like Procter & Gamble and J P Morgan Chase are changing Web strategies to find ways to integrate into online communities; Google, which just purchased YouTube for $1.65 billion, agrees to pay News Corp $900 million to sell advertising on MySpace; Microsoft sells ads for second-largest social networking site Facebook and its own blogging service Live Spaces; users accept advertisers as long as they continue to be relevant and fit in with culture of Web site; advertisers do best online when they accept certain level of unpredictability and allow less control; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Advertisers hope to use social networking sites to get the attention of tens of millions of young people who increasingly avoid television commercials.

''Hi, YouTube, this is Chad and Steve,'' said the taller one with the long hair, punctuating his sentences with ''Um'' and ''You know,'' standing in a parking lot outside of what appeared to be a TGI Friday's.

docs.lead_paragraph: Corporations are growing increasingly conscious of the power, and potential pitfalls, of blogging. A favorable review from an influential blogger can help generate the kind of buzz around a new product that traditional advertising struggles to achieve. A negative write-up can help doom a product before it even hits the market. Now many American brands, and some brands in other countries, are starting to include blogs in their marketing plans, and are catering to them at a much earlier stage. By the time of its official introduction, a product may already have been in the hands of bloggers for several months. Feedback from their online discussions with other devotees can help inform a marketer's subsequent advertising and media strategy.

headline.main: 55 Million Blogs, and Now A Service to Track Them

docs.abstract: Technorati blog-tracking service, in partnership with Edelman public relations firm, provides global survey of blog use; study ranks blogs by region and gauges influence according to number of links from other blogs; Edelman is sponsoring development of new Technorati sites in French, German, Italian, Korean, and Chinese; monitoring blogs presents huge challenge with over 55 million around world and growing at rate of thousands each week; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The Edelman public relations firm is sponsoring development of Technorati sites to monitor blogs written in French, German, Italian, Korean and Chinese.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Association of National Advertisers, New York, elected new officers at its 96th annual conference. Stephen G. Sullivan, senior vice president for communications at the Liberty Mutual Group, was elected the chairman for 2006-8. He succeeds James R. Stengel, global marketing officer at the Procter & Gamble Company, who was the 2004-6 chairman. Mr. Sullivan had been the vice chairman of the association for 2004-6. Rebecca Saeger, chief marketing officer at the Charles Schwab Corporation, was elected the vice chairwoman for 2006-8, placing her in line to be chairwoman in 2008-10. Cheryl Berman, chairwoman at Leo Burnett North America, Chicago, part of the Leo Burnett Worldwide unit of the Publicis Groupe, is leaving the agency at the end of the year to work on an independent venture centered on communications services for women. Burnett has no plans to fill her post. Ms. Berman worked at Burnett for her entire agency career and held a number of senior management jobs at the agency, including United States chief creative officer.

docs.lead_paragraph: AS Dan Firger, a law student at New York University, strolls from class to class during the course of his day or pauses for a breather in Washington Square Park, his cellphone is routinely buzzing inside his messenger bag. He can often guess who it is: Google. Six to eight times a day text messages pop up, courtesy of Google Calendar, a free daily organizer introduced this year. The program can scan appointments and send reminders of coming events.

headline.main: Planet Google Wants You

docs.abstract: Comment on Google as seemingly everpresent in lives of communications-dependent people like New York law student Dan Firger, who scours Web with its search engine, chats with friends using Google Talk and get e-mail on Google Gmail account; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The Web giant, adding YouTube, seeks a mind meld with its users.

docs.lead_paragraph: IS Google's $1.65 billion acquisition of the video Web site YouTube another milestone in the annals of the Internet? Or is it evidence of a second silly season? The answer to both questions: Yep, you'd better believe it. The terms of this all-stock deal are a marvel, given YouTube's age (18 months), revenue (negligible) and profitability (nil). As we were in the dot-com bubble a few years ago, we are back in a moment of ''metrics'' that can make the acquisition appear quite reasonable -- a bargain even -- when measured by nonfinancial considerations like ''uniques'' and ''trailing 12-month page views.''

headline.main: A Loopy Deal That Actually Makes Sense

docs.abstract: Discussion of pros and cons of Google's $1.65 billion acquisition of YouTube; full implications of big media's pragmatic approach toward large Internet endeavors are, at best, murky; observers note it is hard to say whether Google is being foolhardy or prescient (M)
docs.snippet: If you're a search company worth $130 billion, why not take a stab?

docs.lead_paragraph: Sony has prevailed in the game wars so far, with consoles judged largely on their power and graphics, and a big library of games. But as it prepares to introduce its PlayStation 3, the battlefield is expanding. Having spotted Microsoft's Xbox 360 a one-year head start, Sony must also show that its new machine can hold its own in Internet-based gaming, its rival's sweet spot.

headline.main: Battleground For Consoles Moves Online

docs.abstract: Sony must show that its new Playstation 3 console can hold its own in Internet-based gaming; company is embarking on worldwide marketing campaign that will collide directly with equally ambitious efforts by Microsoft; plans to introduce new console in less than month; contends PlayStation 3's powerful hardware makes it best investment, even at higher price; console's base price will be $499, compared with $299 for Xbox 360 and $249 for Nintendo's Wii; Microsoft has been promoting Xbox Live, $50-a-year networking service that lets users play together in casual games or enter tournaments (M)
docs.snippet: With the arrival of its PlayStation 3 nearing, Sony is aiming at its rival's sweet spot: Internet-based gaming.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTEL EARNINGS FALL Intel, the world's largest chip maker, reported a 35 percent decline in third-quarter profit, but still managed to beat Wall Street estimates. Andy Bryant, the chief financial officer, said Intel's fierce price war with Advanced Micro Devices, was likely to ease during the fourth quarter. Fourth-quarter profit would be roughly in line with analysts' forecasts, the company said. [Page C2] CHINESE CAR EXPORTS Despite anxiety that China might soon begin to flood foreign markets with its car exports, it appears that it will be several years before Chinese automakers start exporting large numbers of cars they both design and make. Plans to sell cars in the United States as soon as 2007 have been pushed back. [C1] EXCHANGE MERGER The Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade, longtime fierce competitors, said they would merge in an $8 billion deal that would create the largest market for financial derivatives contracts in the world. [C1] MANHATTAN REAL ESTATE DEAL Jerry I. Speyer, a property magnate who controls some of the New York's most prominent landmarks, from Rockefeller Center to the Chrysler Building agreed to pay $5.4 billion for Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, a vast corridor of 110 apartments along the East River. [A1] HOLLYWOOD INVESTIGATION Prosecutors have called at least 10 lawyers from the firm of Bertram H. Fields before a grand jury in what defense lawyers say is a last-ditch effort to connect Mr. Fields, the Hollywood lawyer, to a wiretapping and conspiracy case against the private investigator Anthony Pellicano. [C6] RATINGS FOR COMMERCIALS An effort by Nielsen Media Research to measure the number of people watching commercials has set off a battle worthy of a ''Survivor'' episode, with just about everyone in the TV and advertising businesses disagreeing over how Nielsen should measure ad viewership. Unable to resolving the disputes, Nielson plans to delay releasing the new ratings until December. Adverstising [C1] SNIPES TAX INDICTMENT A grand jury in Tampa, Fla., has indicted the actor Wesley Snipes, star of the ''Blade'' trilogy and other films, on tax fraud and conspiracy charges after a four-year investigation by the Internal Revenue Service. [E3] BRITISH STEEL BID The Corus Group of Britain said it had received a takeover bid of £4.1 billion ($7.6 billion), from Tata Steel of India. If successful, the deal would create the world's sixth-largest steel company. [C3] NEW DIABETES DRUG Federal drug regulators approved a new diabetes medicine from Merck that is expected to become a blockbuster treatment used by millions of people. Januvia is a once-daily pill that has fewer severe side effects than existing diabetes medications and does not cause weight gain. [C3] WALL STREET EARNINGS Merrill Lynch followed its Wall Street rivals by reporting third-quarter earnings that were stronger than expected, fueled by its debt and equity markets business. Merrill also joined its peers in taking more risk in allocating its capital. [C12] WHOLESALE PRICES FALL A sharp drop in the price of gasoline helped push the Producer Price Index down a sharp 1.3 percent in September. Excluding food and energy, however, the core index rose a greater-than-expected 0.6 percent. [C3] VIDEO GAME WARS With the arrival of its PlayStation 3 less than a month away, Sony is about to embark on a marketing campaign that will collide with an equally ambitious effort by Microsoft. Having spotted Microsoft's Xbox 360 a one-year head start, Sony must show that its new console can hold its own in Internet-based gaming, its rival's sweet spot. And both will face a challenge from the lower-priced Nintendo Wii. [C1] LABOR LEADER ARRESTED Brian M. McLaughlin, a Queens assemblyman who as head of the nation's biggest municipal labor council personified New York City's powerful labor movement, was arrested on federal charges of embezzlement, receiving bribes, fraud and money laundering, charges. [A1] CITIGROUP DEAL IN TURKEY Citigroup said it would pay $3.1 billion for a 20 percent stake in Akbank, a premier Turkish bank It was Citigroup's first deal since the Federal Reserve lifted its ban on acquisitions this spring, and Charles O. Prince III's biggest purchase since taking over three years ago as chief executive. [C4] COURIC IN THIRD Katie Couric has passed the six-week mark on the ''CBS Evening News'' having fallen behind NBC and ABC in the ratings in recent weeks and having lost much of the momentum her program had early on. [E1] SHORTAGE OF ELDERLY SPECIALISTS As the United States population ages, geriatricians -- doctors who specialize in illnesses of the elderly -- are increasingly in short supply. It is a specialty of little interest to medical students, suggesting the shortage will get worse. [A1] MORGAN STANLEY SETTLEMENT The New York Attorney General, Eliot Spitzer, said that Morgan Stanley had agreed to pay more than $1 million to settle a case in which it reportedly failed to supervise a broker who defrauded 15 clients. [C12]

docs.lead_paragraph: For more than two decades, Microsoft's software and Intel's processors were so wedded that the pairing came to be known as Wintel. But as that computing era wanes, Microsoft is turning to a new source of chip design: its own labs. The design effort will initially be split between research labs at the company's headquarters in Redmond, Wash., and its Silicon Valley campus here. Tentatively named the Computer Architecture Group, the project underscores sweeping changes in the industry.

headline.main: Microsoft Looks Within To Design and Test Chips

docs.abstract: Microsoft establishes chip design effort, tentatively called Computer Architecture Group, at research labs in Redmond, Wash, and Mountain View, Calif; veteran engineer Charles Thacker, who will head Silicon Valley group, cites need to begin thinking about next-generation design of its Xbox game console; says new set of tools will make it possible to test ideas quickly without cost of making finished chips; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Microsoft is exploring hardware design now in part because of a new set of tools that will make it possible to test ideas quickly.

docs.lead_paragraph: Invisibility has long been the stuff of fantasy, from Plato's story of the ring of Gyges to Harry Potter's mischief-enabling cloak. But scientists led by a team at Duke University have demonstrated a technology that could be a small step in the right misdirection. The system, a set of concentric copper circles on fiberglass board, deflects electromagnetic waves of a specific frequency that strike it, without much of the scattering and absorption that make reflections and shadows.

headline.main: Cloaking Copper, Scientists Take Step Toward Invisibility

docs.abstract: Scientific team including David R Smith of Duke and Sir John Pendry of Imperial College develop techology leading into fantasy realm of invisibility; set of concentric copper circles on fiberglass board deflects certain electromagnetic waves, without much of scattering and absorption that make reflections and shadows; Smith warns that cloaking device in visible spectrum would be vastly more complex since device would have to warp all of wavelengths of light (S)
docs.snippet: The system, a set of concentric copper circles on fiberglass board, deflects electromagnetic waves of a specific frequency that strike it.

docs.lead_paragraph: Laying the groundwork for a battle against rival Microsoft, Sony said Thursday that 21 games would be available for the PlayStation 3 console when it goes on sale next month. The company said the first 500,000 buyers of the $500 console in North America would get a free copy of the comedy ''Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby,'' a move designed to promote the console's ability to play high-definition DVD's in Sony's Blu-ray format.

docs.lead_paragraph: APPLE PROFIT TOPS ESTIMATES -- Apple Computer said that its fourth-quarter profit jumped 27 percent amid strong sales of Macintosh computers and iPod portable music players. Apple said brisk back-to-school sales were a major reason behind the results, which topped Wall Street estimates by a wide margin. Apple shares climbed as much as 6 percent in after-hours trading. [Page C1] VIRTUAL WORLD ADVERTISING -- Companies including Sony BMG Music Entertainment, Sun Microsystems and Nissan are testing the next frontier in Internet advertising: placing ads into online virtual worlds like Second Life and Virtual Laguna Beach. Some online users worry that the corporate intrusion will spoil their virtual paradises. [C1] MICROSOFT LOOKS AT CHIP DESIGN -- After wedding its software to Intel's processors for decades, Microsoft is looking to its own research labs for as a new source in future chip design. One goal of the project is to give Microsoft more control over hardware and software and the way the interact in new devices. [C3] CONSUMER PRICES FALL -- Falling energy prices helped push consumer prices down sharply last month, but the decline did not entirely dispel inflation worries because the measure of retail prices that excludes food and energy costs held steady at a level still above the Federal Reserve's comfort zone. [C3] NEW AD AGENCY NETWORK -- Three longtime advertising executives are joining forces to start an agency network with an entrepreneurial bent. The agency network, called the Partners Group, aims to grow by encouraging more entrepreneurs to affiliate with the three founders. Advertising [C13] MUSIC INDUSTRY AND YOUTUBE -- Universal Music Group, Sony BMG Music Entertainment and Warner Music each acquired small stakes in YouTube as part of licensing deals just prior to the sale of the company to Google for $1.65 billion. The three companies now stand to receive as much as $50 million collectively, people involved in the deal said. [C1] A TORRENT OF IMMIGRANT MONEY -- The flow of money from immigrants working in the United States to Latin America has become a torrent, increasing by 51 percent from two years ago to over $45 billion, according to a new study. Where 20 years ago such remittances came from four or five states, today they come nearly every state in the country, the study said. [A24] ELI LILLY CRITICIZED -- Three doctors at the National Institutes of Health have sharply criticized Eli Lilly for its efforts to promote the use of Xigris, an expensive treatment for patients with sepsis, an often deadly blood infection. In an article in The New England Journal of Medicine, the doctors wrote that Lilly had manipulated treatment guidelines to promote Xigris at the expense of older, cheaper and equally effective treatments. [C12] TIME WARNER CABLE SHARES -- Time Warner Cable said that it would sell shares publicly for the first time, giving investors a chance to own a piece of the country's second-largest cable provider after Comcast. The shares would amount to 16 percent of the company's equity. [C5] EARNINGS RISE AT A.M.D. -- Advanced Micro Devices, which makes computer processors, posted a higher quarterly profit but profit margins fell sharply, hurt by a price war with the rival chipmaker Intel. Advanced Micro said it expected fourth-quarter sales to rise from the previous quarter but did not elaborate. [C4] NBC PLANS CUTBACKS -- NBC will announce a series of cost-cutting measures including some employee layoffs, executives said. The plans will include a relocation of MSNBC, the all-news cable channel owned by NBC from its current home in Secaucus N.J. [C13] VIACOM SEVERANCE -- Viacom plans to pay its former chief executive, Tom Freston, $84.8 million after ousting him last month after less than a year in the top job. Mr. Freston will receive $58.9 million in severance. The remainder will be in deferred compensation, retirement funds and common stock, the company said in a regulatory filing. [C15] BLOOMBERG NEWS NOT FOR SALE -- Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has rejected bids for Bloomberg LP, the financial information company that he founded in 1981, and has no immediate intention to sell the business, the company said. The statement came amid speculation that the company might be sold to free up Mr. Bloomberg's vast personal wealth for philanthropic causes. [C1] DOW MOVES BRIEFLY PAST 12,000 -- The Dow Jones industrial average briefly swept past the 12,000 mark for the first time as investors showed optimism about corporate earnings and the economy. Then the blue-chip index pulled back, closing at another record high but short of 12,000. [C15] ONLINE DEALBOOK -- A report on mergers and acquisitions, up-to-the-minute news on Wall Street and a look at the behind-the-scenes maneuvering is at nytimes.com/dealbook. A SPECIAL REPORT -- For mutual fund investors, jubilance over gains in the stock market has been tempered by the realization that many fund managers were caught flat-footed and did not keep pace. A report is at nytimes.com/business. TAXES AND FAITH -- A number of communities around the country are debating whether or not religious organizations should receive property tax breaks. An audio slide show is at nytimes.com/business.

The deal, announced yesterday by the dialysis provider, Fresenius Medical Care, comes as Roche is preparing to enter the market next year with a drug that would offer the first competition to Amgen's drug, which is known as Epogen.

headline.main: Kidney Dialysis Center Deal With Amgen Blocks Roche

docs.abstract: Amgen, in move that could help preserve its lucrative monopoly on anemia drugs Epogen and Aranesp, reaches agreement that will make it sole supplier of Epogen to kidney dialysis provider Fresenius Medical Care; move comes as Roche prepares to enter market next year with competitive drug CERA, form of erythropoietin it says can be given less frequently than Amegen's drugs (M)
docs.snippet: Amgen reached an agreement that will make it the sole supplier of an anemia drug to a main operator of kidney dialysis centers.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Perfect Thing How the iPod Shuffles Commerce, Culture and Coolness By Steven Levy 284 pages. Simon & Schuster. $25. Steven Levy, the author of ''The Perfect Thing,'' is madly in love. So what if the object of his affections is inanimate and very, very petite? It makes great company and is fun to fondle. It makes him feel good and bolsters his self-confidence. And size is no problem: the more it shrinks, the more ''adorable'' it becomes.

headline.main: His Heart Belongs to (Adorable) iPod

docs.abstract: Janet Maslin reviews book The Perfect Thing: How the iPod Shuffles Commerce, Culture and Coolness by Steven Levy; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Gushing aside, Steven Levy’s book does a handy job of crystallizing and commemorating the dawn of the iPod age.

docs.lead_paragraph: GOOGLE KEEPS ON GROWING -- Google, the world's largest search engine company, said that its profits nearly doubled from a year ago, maintaining a torrid growth rate at a time when rivals like Yahoo appeared to be faltering. Google said it earned $733 million in the third quarter, up 92 percent from a year ago. Revenue climbed to $2.69 billion, with 44 percent of that coming from outside the United States. [Page C3.] DOW ABOVE 12,000 -- The Dow Jones industrial average closed above the psychologically important 12,000 level for the first time, indicating that investors were increasingly confident that the economy was poised to perform the rare feat of slowing without stalling. The performance in the months ahead will depend, in part, how gracefully the economy handles the slowing housing market. [C1.] BIG BANK EARNINGS -- Citigroup seemed to stumble and Bank of America appeared to strut through a messy third quarter as the country's two biggest banks contended with pressures of a slowing economy and higher interest rates. [C3] CBS SETTLES ACCUSATIONS -- CBS became the first radio corporation to settle accusations of illicit pay-for-play practices made by Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general. CBS, which runs approximately 180 radio stations, agreed to adopt more stringent policies on its stations' dealings with record labels and to make a $2 million payment to New York charities. [C3.] MEDICINE VS. MARKETING -- For many doctors, it's an irresistible pitch: a $250 profit from a 15-minute test. With that lure, some 12,000 of the nation's physicians have purchased an automated device that checks patients for nerve disease. Specialists say the problem is that many general practitioners are not qualified to do such tests. [A1.] HIGHER PROFITS AT DRUG MAKERS -- Drug makers continued to post strong profit gains, led by Pfizer, the world's biggest pharmaceutical company, which reported that its third-quarter earnings had more than doubled from a year earlier. Eli Lilly, Novartis, and Wyeth also reported higher quarterly profits. [C2] VIDEO GAME WARS -- Laying the groundwork for a battle against rival Microsoft, Sony said that 21 games would be available for the PlayStation 3 game console when it goes on sale next month. Sony also plans to highlight the console's ability to play high-definition DVD's in Sony's Blu-ray format. [C11.] BANNER YEAR IN HONG KONG -- In a reflection of China's growing prominence in international finance, Hong Kong is set for a banner year in global markets with more money raised by companies selling shares to the public here than on the biggest exchanges in New York and London. Pricing will be set today for the world's largest IPO ever, that of China's biggest bank, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China. [C1.] BEYOND REGULATORS' REACH -- Every month, roughly 19,000 households across the country write check to Christian Care Ministry. The members pool their health expenses and contributions and the ministry writes checks to health care providers. Such payments totaled $57 million in the latest fiscal year. While ministry members say they are helping to carry each others burdens, some Florida state officials see what they would call unregulated health insurance. [C1.] RULING AGAINST GRASSO -- A New York judge ruled that Richard A. Grasso, a former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, would have to return as much as $100 million of a fiercely contested $139.5 million retirement payout to the exchange The judge, Justice Charles E. Ramos of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, said that Mr. Grasso did not disclose to his fellow directors on the board of the exchange the extent to which his soaring compensation had caused his pension and savings to balloon. [A1.] MERGER REVERBERATIONS -- The $8 billion combination of Chicago's derivatives markets is being heralded as good for Chicago and good for the exchanges. But in Europe, it is raising concerns at banks and rival exchanges that it may increase costs or stifle competition. One of the biggest fears in London where the local derivatives exchange will be dwarfed, is that it creates a so-called vertical silo, or a market where one giant entity is both a trading platform and a clearing system. [C8.] NBC STAFF CUTBACKS -- NBC said it planned to reduce its 6,000-person newsgathering staff by an estimated 5 percent, or 300 people to adapt to the migration of news viewers to the Internet and eliminate overlaps in news coverage. Steve Capus, president of NBC News, said the bulk of the cuts would come from eliminating jobs already vacant, as well as from early retirements and voluntary buyouts, but that some layoffs were inevitable. [C4.] LOWER COST PROGRAMMING -- As part of the extensive cost-cutting program it announced yesterday, NBC intends to dramatically alter its prime-time programming, starting in the fall of 2007, filling the 8 p.m. hour each night of the week with lower-cost, unscripted programs and saving its more expensive scripted comedies and dramas for the 9-to-11 block. [C1.] WEAK NEWSPAPER PROFITS -- Newspaper companies continued to show weakness, with The New York Times Company and the Tribune Company both reporting lackluster earnings, citing soft advertising sales as a major culprit. At the Times Company, the slowdown ''is expected to continue through the end of the year,'' said Janet L. Robinson, the company's president and chief executive. [C7.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. McDonald's reported a 15 percent rise in third-quarter profitmeeting a better-than-expected forecast it gave last week. (REUTERS) The UnitedHealth Group, the nation's largest provider of health insurance, said third-quarter net income rose 38 percent after acquisitions raised the number of policyholders. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) Travelers packed planes operated by Continental Airlines and Southwest Airlines over the summer, but Continental's third-quarter profit grew while Southwest's earnings fell in another sign that traditional carriers were narrowing the gap with low-cost rivals. (AP)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Dow Jones industrial average closed above the 12,000 mark for the first time yesterday, but looking ahead, the stock market's performance in the coming year will largely hinge on how gracefully the economy handles the troubled housing market. The Dow squeaked by 12,000 after two weeks of gains, indicating that investors are increasingly confident that the economy is poised to perform the relatively rare feat of slowing without stalling. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, a broader measure of the market, has also done well and is up 9.5 percent for the year.

headline.main: How Far Past 12,000? Watch Data

docs.lead_paragraph: SEDUCTIVELY lighted music players may be hogging retail shelf space, but their overshadowed cousin, the portable media player, is looking increasingly attractive. A new generation of portable media players -- primarily designed to play video but, in some instances, to record it -- is arriving in stores and on the Web. Many of the players are svelte, easy to use and less expensive than their predecessors. They can hold music videos or full-length movies, as well as play music and display digital photos. And more consumers are taking notice.

headline.main: Portable Media Players Aim for the Masses

docs.abstract: Article on new generation of portable media players that can hold music videos or full-length movies as well as play music and display digital photos; consumers and retailers say new devices are popular because of their smaller size and weight, drop in prices, high storage capacity and recording options; some of latest devices described; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Lower prices? That's only the beginning.

Mack, an influential Wall Street executive.

byline.original: By WALT BOGDANICH and GRETCHEN MORGENSON

docs.lead_paragraph: PUBLICLY traded American companies hold so much cash that, as a group, they could pay off all their debt and still have money left over. According to a new study, this cash-heavy status reflects a major shift over the last two decades, and it isn't necessarily a good sign for stocks. The study has been circulating since September as a National Bureau of Economic Research working paper. It is titled ''Why Do U.S. Firms Hold So Much More Cash Than They Used To?,'' and its authors are Thomas W. Bates and Kathleen M. Kahle, finance professors at the University of Arizona, and René M. Stulz, a professor of banking and monetary economics at Ohio State. A version is at nber.org/papers/w12534.

headline.main: Behind Those Stockpiles of Corporate Cash

docs.abstract: Mark Hulbert Strategies column holds publicly traded American companies hold so much cash that, as group, they could pay off all of their debt and still have money left over; says study by Profs Thomas W Bates, Kathleen M Kahle and Rene M Stulz says cash-heavy status reflects major shift over last two decades, and it is not necessarily good sign for stocks; says professors found that average cash-to assets ratio for corporations more than doubled from 1980 to 2004, to 24 percent from 10.5 percent; professors contend that increase resulted from nothing more than cash hoarding at just few large companies; say main cause of climb in corporate cash is increase in risk--as evidenced by factors like unpredictable cash flow; say corporations have become less able to count on steady cash flow from year to year and despite growth of complex derivatives market, companies cannot adequately hedge this risk without holding more cash; add it explains why so few companies are paying out their bigger cash hoards as dividends; graph (L)
docs.snippet: Cash rich, dividend poor, and risk prone?

docs.lead_paragraph: FIBER networks cross the world. Data bits move at light speed. The globe has been flattened, and national boundaries obliterated. Yet in Silicon Valley, the one place that is responsible more than any other for creating the network technology that supposedly renders geography irrelevant, physical distance is very much on the minds of the investors who provide venture capital. Meet the ''20-minute rule'' that guides fateful decisions in Silicon Valley. Craig Johnson, managing director of Concept2Company Ventures, a venture capital firm in Palo Alto, Calif., who has 30 years of experience in early-stage financings, said he knew many venture capitalists who adhered to this doctrine: if a start-up company seeking venture capital is not within a 20-minute drive of the venture firm's offices, it will not be funded.

headline.main: It's Not Who You Know. It's Where You Are.

docs.lead_paragraph: A restaurant chain that celebrates a time when diners had tabletop jukeboxes is sponsoring a promotion featuring contemporary music and new technology to help update its appeal for a generation that prefers hip-hop to doo-wop. The chain is Johnny Rockets, which opened its first restaurant, in Los Angeles, in 1986, and has since grown to almost 200 outlets in 29 states and 10 countries. The campaign, created by Cornerstone Promotion in New York, includes free downloads from eMusic, a Johnny Rockets page on MySpace (myspace.com/johnnyrockets), customized mix lists, ''genealogy'' charts that connect classic songs to the output of today's artists, iPod giveaways, promotions on college radio stations and special content on the Johnny Rockets Web site (johnnyrockets.com).

docs.lead_paragraph: Over the last six years, Internap Network Services has survived hundreds of layoffs, a tumbling share price and a delisting threat from Nasdaq. Until this year, it had never been profitable. Still, it was fortunate to be in a business, renting data center space, in which many of its competitors had gone under. After 10 years in business, Internap has made money for the last two quarters. The company is opening or expanding centers here and in Manhattan, Boston and Toronto. All told, the expansion should increase space in Internap-owned data centers, now at 84,051 square feet, by about 14 percent. Revenue is expected to jump 12 to 15 percent this year.

docs.snippet: The good times are back for data center operators. Over the next 10 years, more than half expect to expand, according to a 2006 survey.

docs.lead_paragraph: Microsoft reported solid quarterly results yesterday that slightly surpassed Wall Street expectations, with sales growth driven by its Xbox game business and software for server computers. Both revenue and profit rose 11 percent. Demand for the company's software for corporate databases and servers grew strongly, with sales up 17 percent, to $2.5 billion. Sales of Xbox game consoles, software and online game subscriptions jumped 70 percent, to more than $1 billion. Those two businesses accounted for most of Microsoft's revenue growth in the quarter, the first in the company's 2007 fiscal year.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court said yesterday that it would intervene in a patent dispute between Microsoft and AT&T over Windows programs distributed overseas. An appeals court ruled last year that Microsoft had infringed on an AT&T patent for a type of speech-coding technology. Dennis Crouch, a visiting law professor at Boston University, said the outcome could be worth more than $1 billion to Microsoft if the justices find that the lower court ruling improperly extended American patent protections to overseas transactions.

[Page C1.] CONGRESS TO REVIEW S.E.C. The Securities and Exchange Commission, under scrutiny for its handling of an insider-trading case involving the prominent hedge fund Pequot Capital and the influential Wall Street executive John J. Mack, above, will be the subject of a broad review by the investigative arm of Congress, the Government Accountability Office. [C1.] DELAY IN TAX COLLECTION -- The commissioner of Internal Revenue ordered his agency to delay collecting back taxes from Hurricane Katrina victims until after the Nov. 7 elections and the holiday season, saying he did so in part to avoid negative publicity. [A1.] LONDON AS FINANCIAL CAPITAL -- Even as the Dow Jones industrial average climbs to new highs and Wall Street companies report robust profits, by some measures New York's long-held crown as the financial capital of the world may be slipping, and London is gaining. [C1.] FLOCKING TO FORT WORTH -- Under golf courses, schools, parks, libraries, airports and dozens of neighborhoods, some of the nation's leading independent energy companies are scouring Fort Worth, Tex., in search of the best locations to recover one of the largest concentrations of natural gas in the United States. [C1.] MICROSOFT BEATS EXPECTATIONS -- Microsoft reported solid quarterly results that slightly surpassed Wall Street expectations, with sales growth driven by its Xbox game business and software for server computers. Both sales and profit rose 11 percent. [C3.] OIL GIANTS POST SOLID RESULTS -- The oil giants Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch Shell reported stronger-than-expected quarterly earnings, showing resilience in the face of recently falling oil and gas prices and rising costs. [C3.] LAWSUIT OVER LIFE SETTLEMENTS -- Coventry First, one of the largest purchasers of life settlements -- arrangements where investors buy life insurance policies owned by the elderly and ill, hoping to earn when sellers' demise -- was sued by the New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, who accused the company of bid-rigging and other types of fraud in acquiring more than $3.6 billion worth of life insurance policies. [C3.] LEGAL SERVICES OUTSOURCED -- The law firm Clifford Chance is set to announce that it will move big chunks of its administrative functions like accounting and technological support to a facility in Delhi, India, by next spring. [C3.] PLAVIX HURT BY CANADIAN RIVAL -- Still reeling from a generic assault on its top-selling product, Plavix, Bristol-Myers Squibb said it lost up to $600 million in sales of the drug to a Canadian rival during the third quarter, accounting for part of a 65 percent decline in earnings. [C4.] STROKE DRUG FAILS IN TRIAL -- An experimental drug called XNY-059 that AstraZeneca had hoped could protect the brain from the damage caused by a stroke has failed in a large clinical trial, the company said. [C4.] SCARY ADS FOR HALLOWEEN -- In the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, many advertising campaigns for Halloween were significantly toned down. Five years on, the horror quotient is being dialed back up to typical levels, replete with all manner of macabre things that go bump in the night. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C5.] AIRBUS ORDER DELAYED -- Virgin Atlantic Airways said it had decided to postpone its order for six Airbus A380 jets by four years, making it the first airline to step back from its commitment to the troubled twin-deck plane and signaling the potential for more trouble. The A380, a 555-seat plane, has been plagued by major production problems, and Airbus has said that the delays could wipe $6 billion off the profit of its parent, European Aeronautic Defense and Space, over four years. [C7.] VIETNAM'S W.T.O. BID APPROVED -- Trade negotiators in Geneva approved the terms of Vietnam's admission to the World Trade Organization, but the biggest winners from its entry will probably not be American. They will probably be European and Asian. [C7.] SHARES MARCH HIGHER -- Stocks extended their rally, pushing the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index toward its best month since 2003, as lower oil prices improved the outlook for companies sensitive to consumer spending. [C8.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. Ford Motor, which this week reported its biggest loss in 14 years, will almost double its purchase of China-made parts this year to cut production costs. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) Raytheon's third-quarter profit rose 41 percent on increased sales of aircraft and systems to coordinate battle operations. (AP) Aetna, one of the nation's largest health insurers, said that third-quarter profit rose 28 percent, driven in part by aggressive campaigns that added more than 700,000 customers in the last year. (AP) Kellogg said third-quarter profit rose 2.5 percent, helped by sales of new snacks and Eggo waffles. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) The US Airways Group, formed last year from the merger of US Airways and America West Airlines, posted a third-quarter net loss after fuel hedging and merger-related costs. docs.lead_paragraph: Stocks pulled back yesterday after a government report stirred concerns that the economy may be slowing too much. Investors have bid up stocks sharply this month on the notion that the economy is slowing but that the slackening pace poses no threat to corporate profits and consumer spending. Investors are also counting on a gradual slowdown to reduce the threat of inflation and persuade the Federal Reserve to lower short-term interest rates.

headline.main: After a Strong Week, a Whimper

docs.lead_paragraph: Over the last two decades, video games have looked better and better. As the simple graphics of the first Atari evolved into the photo-realistic images of the new Xbox 360, the revenue picture also improved until an industry emerged from the toy department and grew to be worth $30 billion a year. It's the oldest story in the technology sector: processing power drives growth. But now, in an effort to change the plot, Nintendo is eschewing speed and graphics quality in favor of an inventive new controller, in the hope of providing a experience that will appeal to casual gamers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Darcy Burner has never held public office -- the former Microsoft project manager is just 35 -- but nonetheless she appears to have a good shot at becoming the first Democratic representative from Washington's Eighth District. The timing of her bid is propitious: in this scandal-saturated election year, her lack of political experience may be a boon. And the fact that Burner is an adept fund-raiser has fueled her quick rise. There's another, slightly more intangible factor at play, too: Evergreen-state residents are accustomed to female leadership. ''You don't have the hurdle of convincing voters that women can do the job when the models include people without a Y chromosome,'' Burner told me recently. And in fact, Washington is the only state in the nation where both senators and the governor are women.

docs.lead_paragraph: GOOD old-fashioned indexing -- the plain-vanilla strategy of buying and holding all the stocks in a broad market benchmark like the Standard & Poor's 500 -- became popular in the late 1990s, when the major stock indexes were returning more than 20 percent a year.
