docs.lead_paragraph: I wouldn't ordinarily allow someone -- let alone a 77-year-old stranger -- to film me from behind. But Vic Braden, the esteemed tennis instructor and author who in the past half-century has coached, advised or athletically analyzed sports figures ranging from Roger Federer to Muhammad Ali's racehorse, uses video playback the way a doctor uses X-rays. ''You're too late,'' he says, replaying my forehand frame by frame in a video room. The posterior view is troubling enough (Braden shoots from behind so that the brain doesn't have to reverse the image), but the backswing is horrifying: high like a Louisville Slugger in a big leaguer's stance.

docs.lead_paragraph: A district court judge in Iowa has ordered Microsoft's chairman, Bill Gates, and chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer, to testify at a trial in Iowa later this month. The company is facing a class-action antitrust lawsuit, which seeks up to $450 million for Iowans who have purchased its software since 1994. The plaintiffs contend that anticompetitive practices by Microsoft caused consumers to pay more for its products than they would have otherwise. Microsoft says its products have been successful because of their low cost and high quality. A jury trial is scheduled to begin in Des Moines on Nov. 13.

docs.lead_paragraph: Microsoft acknowledged the influence of the Linux operating system on Thursday by striking a deal with Novell, a longtime rival, to ensure that Novell's version of Linux could operate together with Windows in corporate data centers. In an industry known for strange bedfellows, the two companies said they were collaborating on technical development and marketing programs. They also took steps to ensure that Microsoft's intellectual property was protected as it modifies its software to work with the operating system Novell acquired in January 2004, known as SuSE Linux.

headline.main: 2 Giants In a Deal Over Linux

docs.abstract: Microsoft strikes deal with Novell to ensure that Novell's version of Linux operating system can operate together with Windows in corporate data centers; rivals are collaborating on technical development and marketing programs and have taken steps to ensure that Microsoft's intellectual property is protected as it modifies its software to work with Novell's SuSE Linux operating system; industry analysts say partnership is driven by both competitive and customer considerations; say it may help Microsoft's fast-growing server software business by reassuring corporate technology managers that they can make continued investments in Windows, which is proprietary, and Linux, which is open-source; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Microsoft struck a deal with Novell to ensure that its version of Linux could operate with Windows in corporate data centers.

docs.lead_paragraph: MICROSOFT AND LINUX -- Microsoft acknowledged the influence of the Linux operating system by striking an agreement with Novell, a longtime rival, to ensure that Novell's version of Linux can operate together with Windows. [Page C1.] CRUISE TO HELP LEAD UNITED ARTISTS -- Tom Cruise, the film star who took a beating when Paramount ended his longstanding production deal last summer, has found not just a home, but a new career direction that could point the way for expensive actors who are struggling in cost-conscious Hollywood. Mr. Cruise and his producing partner, Paula Wagner, will take charge of United Artists, the production company started by Charlie Chaplin and Mary Pickford. [C1.] NEW MEDICAID POLICY -- Under a new federal policy, children born in the United States to illegal immigrants with low incomes will no longer be automatically entitled to health insurance through Medicaid, Bush administration officials said. [A1.] DISAPPOINTING RETAIL SALES -- Wal-Mart Stores was one of several large retailers, along with Target and CostCo, to post disappointing October sales totals. [C1.] UTILITY SWITCH -- On Tuesday, voters in Yolo County in California will decide whether residents will switch from Pacific Gas and Electric to the municipal utility. Supporters of the change say it will lower costs. Opponents, including P.G.&E., are afraid it will set a bad precedent. [C1.] HOME OWNERSHIP AD CAMPAIGN -- The National Association of Realtors will begin promoting the notion that buying a home is an unalloyed good in a $40 million campaign that boldly declares: ''It's a great time to buy or sell a home.'' Advertising. [C7.] EX-CHIEF SENTENCED TO 12 YEARS -- The former chief executive of Computer Associates International, Sanjay Kumar, was sentenced yesterday to 12 years in prison for orchestrating a $2.2 billion accounting fraud at the software company. He was also fined $8 million. [C3.] HINT IN EUROPE ON RATES -- The European Central Bank signaled that it would raise its benchmark interest rate for the sixth time in a year when it meets in December, as it tries to curb inflation in an expanding European economy. [C5.] RUSSIA PRESSURES GEORGIA ON OIL -- Russia intensified its economic pressure on Georgia as the state-controlled gas monopoly, Gazprom, indicated that it would seek to more than double the price it charges for natural gas, beginning in January. [A12.] ARRESTS IN ONLINE THEFTS -- At least three Americans and 11 Polish nationals have been arrested in the last month in a crackdown on an online black market in which users buy and sell credit card numbers, bank account log-ins and other information, federal investigators say. [C4.] RUNWAY ERRORS NOT UNCOMMON -- Using the wrong runway, the error that led to the crash in Kentucky that killed 49 people in August, is not so rare, a top official of the Federal Aviation Administration said at a safety conference. [A21.] INSTINET IS SOLD -- Less than a year after buying Instinet, the electronic brokerage firm, the private equity firm Silver Lake Partners has agreed to sell the company. [C3.] LOWER INCOME AT CBS -- CBS reported lower net income from a year ago, when it was still combined with Viacom, but operating earnings rose. The company also announced a share buyback of up to $1.5 billion. Investors have been pressing CBS to say what its plans are for its growing cash stockpile, which is at $3.2 billion. [C4.] JANITORS STRIKE IN HOUSTON -- More than 5,000 janitors have gone on strike because five Houston cleaning companies have rejected their proposal for a salary increase to $8.50 an hour, up from the current average of $5.25 an hour. [A18.] CHINA AND AFRICA -- China is courting Africa with both economic and political goals in mind. Its economic goal is to secure Africa's abundant supplies of oil, iron ore, copper and cotton at the lowest possible prices, analysts say. [A1.] STOCKS FALL -- Stocks continued to decline, dipping lower after the Labor Department said productivity was flat in the third quarter while wages rose nearly 4 percent. The data raised concerns that the Federal Reserve would continue to wrestle with inflation, possibly raising interest rates again. [C7.]

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 Federal Web Site Offers Clues to Build Atom Bomb The federal government set up a Web site to make public a vast archive of Iraqi documents captured during the war. But some of the documents posted, weapons experts say, are themselves a danger, including some that may constitute a basic guide to building an atom bomb. A1 Tucked away in a huge military authorization bill signed by President Bush is what some of Stuart W. Bowen Jr.'s supporters believe is his reward for embarrassing the administration with investigations into reconstruction money spent in Iraq: a pink slip, in the form of an obscure provision terminating the federal oversight agency that he heads. A1 China Continues to Court Africa Beijing has put on its best face to court Africa as political leaders of 48 of the 53 African countries are to arrive in Beijing this weekend for a huge diplomatic event. A1 Delayed Thai Democracy Six weeks after a bloodless coup in Thailand, the mess of politics has reasserted itself and the generals are fumbling a bit with their new image as managers. Complaints have begun that these fix-it men have not produced ''instant democracy.'' A3 South African AIDS Fight Departing from years of indecision and, on occasion, denial, South Africa's government is considering a new and sweeping assault on an AIDS pandemic that already includes one in eight of the world's H.I.V. infections. A4 NATIONAL A18-25 Candidates Struggle to Win Women's Votes in Virginia In Virginia, Senator George Allen, a Republican, and Jim Webb, a Democrat, are locked in an exceedingly tight contest, one of a handful that will determine control of the Senate. But the real struggle may be about winning the votes of women. A1 In what Democrats have worked hard to portray as a ''culture of corruption'' in the Republican Party, more than a dozen Republicans in House races have wrestled with the taint of a Congressional page scandal and links to Jack Abramoff. Still, there are Democrats whose campaigns have also been marked by claims of ethical failings. A23 New Medicaid Rules Announced Under a new federal policy, children born in the United States to undocumented immigrants with low incomes will no longer be automatically entitled to health insurance through Medicaid, Bush administration officials said. A1 War Crime Trials to Begin The Pentagon expects to begin conducting the first war crimes trials at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, under the new military commission law by summer, senior military officials have said. A18 Dire Warning on Fishing If fishing around the world continues at its present pace, more species will vanish, marine ecosystems will unravel and there will be ''global collapse'' of all species currently fished, possibly as soon as midcentury, fisheries experts and ecologists are predicting. A21 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Lieberman's Failed '04 Run Hardened Independence Senator Joseph I. Lieberman's rejection by the Democratic Party in the waning days of his failed presidential run in 2004 played a role in his decision to run for re-election in Connecticut on his own party line, according to some friends and advisers. B1 High Stakes for Corzine Gov. Jon S. Corzine has worked behind the scenes to get his handpicked Democratic candidate, Robert Menendez, elected in the race for United States Senate in New Jersey. A defeat would be particularly stinging for Mr. Corzine, in part because a Democratic loss could cost the party control of the Senate. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-10 Microsoft Links With Novell Microsoft acknowledged the influence of the Linux operating system by striking a deal with Novell, a longtime rival, to ensure that Novell's version of Linux can operate together with Windows in corporate data centers. Columns: Paul Krugman, Thomas L. Friedman. OBITUARIES B8-9 Mose Tolliver A folk artist whose work made him one of the leaders of the modern-day Outsider Art movement, he was in his 80s. docs.lead_paragraph: When the liberal talk radio network Air America filed for bankruptcy protection last month, some analysts blamed a lack of listener interest in progressive talk radio. Now, it seems that a lack of major advertising dollars are responsible. In a memo dated Oct. 25, ABC Radio Networks instructed affiliated stations that broadcast syndicated programs from Air America to black out all ads from Hewlett-Packard, which had purchased advertising time on ABC but did ''not wish to air on any Air America affiliates.'' The memo listed almost 90 advertisers that it said were taking part in blackouts of Air America, including Microsoft, Wal-Mart, Visa, Exxon Mobil, Cingular, McDonald's, the United States Postal Service and the Navy.

headline.main: Some Advertisers Shun Air America, a Lonely Voice From Talk Radio's Left

docs.abstract: Memo released by radio talk show host Peter B Collins shows ABC Radio Networks ordered blackouts involving almost 90 advertisers who did not want to air on liberal talk radio network Air America; lack of major advertising dollars most likely led to network filing for bankruptcy protection last month; companies involved in blackouts included Microsoft, Wal-Mart, Visa, Exxon Mobil, Cingular, McDonald's and United States Postal Service (M)
docs.snippet: It seems that a lack of major advertising dollars was responsible for Air America filing for bankruptcy protection last month.

docs.lead_paragraph: The movement known as the netroots -- that amalgam of bloggers and online fund-raisers -- has grown more forceful with every election cycle and played a part in the Democratic primaries this year. But will it help tip the balance in Congress? One race to watch is in Pennsylvania's Eighth Congressional District, where PATRICK MURPHY of Philadelphia is running to unseat Representative MICHAEL G. FITZPATRICK, the Republican. Mr. Murphy, an Army paratrooper in Iraq two years ago, is among the veterans known as the Fighting Dems -- born of the netroots and beneficiaries of their campaign efforts. In Washington's Eighth, DARCY BURNER, a Democrat and former Microsoft executive, is using her tech savvy to try to beat Representative DAVE REICHERT, a Republican in his first term. If JIM WEBB, who raised loads of money online and benefited as his opponent's ''macaca'' moment went straight to YouTube, wins in Virginia, technology will get credit. That's doubly true for NED LAMONT, the most famous candidate of the blogosphere, but polls have shown him running well behind in the Connecticut Senate race. ANNE E. KORNBLUT

docs.lead_paragraph: I didn't even touch on the impact of the Internet,'' Michael Kinsley noted in an e-mail message about his cover essay, ''Election Day,'' evidently as surprised as we were. Kinsley is, of course, one of the founders of the Internet news revolution, and still writes a column for Slate, the online publication he started in 1996. ''The Web is far and away the most important development in journalism -- and almost every other aspect of life -- since I finished school and started working,'' he went on. ''When Microsoft hired me to put out what became Slate, the economy and the immediacy were what appealed to me about the Internet. Imagine: there were tiny businesses in suburban shopping malls that could 'publish' the equivalent of The New Republic (where I then worked) and it would cost less than $10,000 a year.''

She applies a little eye makeup and arrives on the Becker College campus for her course on principles of teaching at 8:20 a.m. She is more than an hour early. She calls ''Hello'' and ''How are you?'' to all the students she passes -- whether or not she knows them -- and then gets a large Green Mountain coffee and listens to Latin rap on her iPod.

docs.lead_paragraph: SIGNS OF A HOUSING BUST -- The striking swing from seller's market to buyer's market in Phoenix tells the tale of a housing bonanza turned bust. The number of unsold homes in the area has soared to almost 46,000 from just a few thousand in early 2005. And builders are pulling back as fast as they can. Around the country, sales cancellations among big builders are running as high as 40 percent, double the rate a year ago. [Page A1.] HAPPY HOLIDAYS ON WALL STREET -- For a fourth consecutive year, year-end bonuses on Wall Street are forecast to be very lucrative, with the payouts rising 10 to 15 percent from 2005. [C1.] VIDEO ON THE XBOX -- Microsoft said that it would offer movies and episodes of television shows for download to its Xbox 360 game consoles, beginning Nov. 22. With the new offerings, Microsoft is joining cable giants and Internet start-ups on the long list of companies hoping to profit from video downloads. [C1.] CHINA TO PASS U.S. AS POLLUTER -- Nearly a decade ahead of previous projections, China will surpass the United States in 2009 as the biggest emitter of the main gas linked to global warming, the International Energy Agency has concluded. [C1.] BID FOR FOUR SEASONS HOTELS -- The chief executive and controlling shareholder of Four Seasons Hotels, Isadore Sharp, made a $3.7 billion buyout bid for the luxury hotel chain, with backing from investment groups led by Bill Gates of Microsoft and Prince Walid bin Talal of the Saudi royal family. [C1.] COMMITTED TO COAL -- The TXU Corporation is planning to add more than 9,000 megawatts of new coal-burning capacity, enough to power millions of homes. It is betting that it can overcome opposition to carbon emissions, placing a $10 billion wager on 11 new coal power plants that will produce copious amounts of global warming gases for decades to come. [C1.] PAYING FOR IDLE FUEL TRUCKS -- A Halliburton subsidiary charged the Iraqi government as much as $25,000 a month for each of as many as 1,800 fuel trucks that were to deliver gasoline to Iraq after the 2003 invasion, but the trucks often spent days or weeks sitting idle on the border, says a report released by an auditing agency sponsored by the United Nations. [A6.] MYSPACE GOES GLOBAL -- MySpace is aggressively trying to move into overseas markets, and is expected to announce today that it is expanding into Japan through a possible joint venture. [C3.] BUSINESS NEWS CHANNEL PICKED UP -- A business-news cable channel planned by the News Corporation has moved a step closer to reality, reaching a deal to be carried by Comcast, the nation's largest cable-television system operator. [C3.] HUMOR FOR THE HOLIDAYS -- Madison Avenue is taking a humorous tack to stimulate sales for the holidays, ranging from wry subtlety to fall-down slapstick, rather than traditionally sentimental, schmaltzy or straightforward. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C3.] OVERSTOCK.COM IN NEED OF CAPITAL -- With sales down and losses up, the Internet retailer Overstock.com warned that it might have to raise capital next year, and added that it did not expect to have its latest problems fixed before Christmas. [C3.] ABBOTT TO BUY DRUG DEVELOPER -- Abbott Laboratories said that it would acquire Kos Pharmaceuticals for $3.7 billion. [C5.] LINDE SELLS DIVISION -- Linde of Germany said it was selling its forklift unit, Kion, to the equity firms Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Goldman Sachs Capital Partners for $5.1 billion. [C8.] GOLD PRODUCER BUYS RIVAL -- Kinross Gold, the Canadian gold producer, agreed to buy a rival, Bema Gold, for $2.55 billion in an all-stock deal. [C8.] ARCELOR'S PRESIDENT TURNED CHIEF -- Lakshmi Mittal, the president of the Arcelor Mittal steel company, tightened his control over the company, succeeding the chief executive Roland Junck. [C8.] FIRST BLACKBERRY, NOW TREO -- NTP, the patent holding company that successfully sued the maker of BlackBerry devices for infringement of wireless e-mail patents, said it was suing Palm, maker of the Treo smartphone. [C9.] DOW GAINS ON MERGERS -- Takeovers spurred the biggest stock-market rally in a month and sent the Dow Jones industrial average to its first gain in seven days. [C10.]

docs.lead_paragraph: After five years and frequent delays, Microsoft announced yesterday that it had finished the new version of its Windows operating system, Windows Vista. The finished code will start going out immediately to many large corporate customers. The formal introduction date for large corporate users will be Nov. 30, with a marketing event in New York. Vista will be available for the home and small-business market, both installed on PCs and sold separately, on Jan. 30, Microsoft confirmed yesterday.

headline.main: After 5 Years, Latest Version Of Windows Is Set to Ship

docs.abstract: Microsoft announces finished version of its Windows Vista operating system after five years of delays; analysts say software is most significant advance company has made in decade; formal introduction of business version is set for November 30, with planned marketing event in New York; home version will be available after holiday season, which may affect sales of personal computers (M)
docs.snippet: Microsoft announced that it had finished the new version of its Windows operating system, Windows Vista.

docs.lead_paragraph: An article in Business Day on Tuesday described a decision by Microsoft to offer movies and episodes of television shows for downloading through its Xbox Live online service in the United States. The article quoted Rob Enderle, principal analyst at the Enderle Group, discussing the features that set Xbox Live service apart and its position in the market. But the article did not note that Mr. Enderle had Microsoft as a client, a fact later pointed out by a reader. Mr. Enderle does consulting work for several of Microsoft's product groups, though not for the one developing the Xbox; still, had The Times known of Mr. Enderle's work for Microsoft, it would not have sought out his opinion on the product.

docs.lead_paragraph: Microsoft is probably the greenest company in all of high tech. Not green in the environmental sense -- green with envy. Microsoft is so jealous of the iPod's success that Tuesday it will unveil a new music system -- pocket player, jukebox software and online music store -- that's an unabashed copy of Apple's. It's called Zune.

headline.main: Trying Out The Zune: IPod It's Not

docs.snippet: It can’t touch the iPod’s looks or coolness, but the new Microsoft Zune is certainly more practical.

docs.lead_paragraph: FORGOING VENTURE CAPITAL -- Hundreds of Internet start-up companies are forgoing venture capital in their early stages, choosing instead to grow on a shoestring, unlike so many companies formed during the first Internet boom that were built on costly technology and marketing budgets. [Page C1.] MICROSOFT TO PAY DEVICE ROYALTY -- Averting a standoff that might have crippled its attempt to compete against the iPod, Microsoft said that it had agreed to pay a percentage of the sales of its new portable media player to Vivendi's Universal Music Group. Universal is expected to receive more than $1 per $250 device, with half of that amount going to its artists. [C1.] WINDOWS CODE COMPLETED -- After five years and frequent delays, Microsoft said it had finished the new version of its Windows operating system, Windows Vista. [C7.] DEMOCRATS PLEDGE COOPERATION -- Democrats may have won big on Tuesday, but the lawmakers who will soon oversee tax, trade and economic issues on Capitol Hill are pledging to seek common ground with the White House and Congressional Republicans. [C1.] INVESTORS BET ON NEW CONGRESS -- Stocks rallied for a third day, sending the Dow Jones industrial average to a record, as investors bet on companies that would benefit from a Democrat-controlled Congress. [C9.] ARMY STARTS AD CAMPAIGN -- Like ads from Ford, which emphasize toughness, and FedEx, which invoke reliability, the United States military is starting a campaign theme called ''Army strong,'' to the tune of $1.35 billion over five years. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C3.] CABLEVISION NARROWS LOSS -- Cablevision reported a narrower third-quarter loss as it signed up more cable customers for premium services like high-speed Internet access and digital phone. [C4.] CISCO'S NET RISES -- Cisco Systems reported a higher-than-expected rise in quarterly profit as businesses upgraded their networks to handle increasing Internet traffic. [C4.] NO MORE BANK TRIPS -- Many small businesses are starting to use scanners designed to turn paper checks into screen images that can be deposited over the Internet, without having to leave the office. [C6.] S.E.C. SUES HEDGE FUND -- The Securities and Exchange Commission sued a San Francisco hedge fund manager, Edward Ehee, and the funds that he managed, accusing him of fleecing investors out of about $5 million. [C7.] CHINA'S SURPLUS SOARS -- China said that its trade surplus with the rest of the world had leapt to a record $23.8 billion in October, the latest sign of this country's phenomenal rise as a trading superpower. [C16.] A.D.M. EYES BIOENERGY -- Archer Daniels Midland's new chief executive outlined a broad strategy for the company to dominate the growing bioenergy industry, but offered few specifics on how it would carry out that vision. [C5.] FUND PRESSURES THE TIMES -- A Morgan Stanley investment fund is stepping up its confrontation with The New York Times Company, submitting a shareholder proposal that urges directors to change the board's governance practices. [C5.] GEFFEN AND THE L.A. TIMES -- The billionaire David Geffen has been prominently linked with a potential sale of The Los Angeles Times, fueled in part by his recent sale of hundreds of millions of dollars worth of paintings. Mr. Geffen, left, is a favorite potential owner among many top editors at the paper, but if he wants it he will have to beat out other billionaires who are gunning for the paper's parent company. [C1.] RIVAL BID FOR TRIBUNE -- Two Los Angeles billionaires, Eli Broad and Ronald W. Burkle, joined forces and submitted a competitive bid to buy the Tribune Company, the owner of The Los Angeles Times and 10 other daily newspapers, according to people close to the investors. [C4.] TOP EDITOR OUT AT INQUIRER -- Amanda Bennett, the editor of The Philadelphia Inquirer, stepped down and was replaced by William K. Marimow, a former Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter for The Inquirer and top news executive with NPR. He takes over as the paper faces layoffs, sinking ad revenue and declining circulation. [C4.] SETBACK FOR CHRYSLER CROSSOVER -- The Chrysler Group has apparently stopped development of the replacement for the Chrysler Pacifica crossover, and it may halt production of the current vehicle a year earlier than scheduled. [C5.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. The News Corporation, the media conglomerate controlled by Rupert Murdoch, swung to a profit in its first fiscal quarter on better results from cable and broadcast TV compared with a year ago, when it recorded a $1 billion accounting charge. (AP) UnitedHealth Group, the health insurer, said that its restatement of earnings to correct accounting for stock-based compensation would be ''significantly greater'' than the $286 million it estimated in May. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) Johnson & Johnson said that its Janssen pharmaceuticals unit had received a subpoena from the California attorney general over the sale and marketing of Risperdal, a schizophrenia drug. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) Evercore Partners, the investment bank led by Roger Altman, a former deputy Treasury secretary, said that its third-quarter profit rose 5.8 percent as a revamping cut compensation costs. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-24 Israeli Tank Shelling Kills 18 Palestinians in Gaza Israeli tank shells killed 18 Palestinians, including 8 children and 6 women, at a cluster of houses in Beit Hanun, one of the largest single losses of life in Gaza in years. Several Hamas leaders called for suicide bombing retaliation inside Israel. A1 42 Killed in Pakistan Attack A suicide bomber detonated his explosives on a military training ground in northwestern Pakistan, killing at least 42 army recruits and wounding about 20 more, government officials said. A24 Iraq Reacts to U.S. Elections Iraq's political leaders scrambled to interpret what a new political landscape in Washington might mean for the future of their war-ravaged country. A18 Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki predicted in a televised interview that former President Saddam Hussein would be hanged by the end of the year. A18 Poll Finds Afghans Losing Hope Afghans have lost a considerable amount of confidence in the direction of their country over the past two years, according to an extensive nationwide survey conducted by the Asia Foundation. A6 Turkey Warned on Cyprus The governing commission of the European Union issued its strongest warning yet to Turkey to open its ports to Cyprus and make more progress on human rights or face a possible suspension of talks over allowing the country to join. A5 THE ELECTIONS P1-16 Rumsfeld to Depart Post, As Democrats Gain Control Faced with the collapse of his Republican majority in Congress, President Bush responded swiftly by announcing the departure of Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and vowing to work with Democrats ''to find common ground'' on the war in Iraq and domestic issues. A1 A.P. Calls Virginia for Webb Despite the fact that Senator George Allen of Virginia had not conceded, Jim Webb, his Democratic opponent, claimed victory on the strength of a 7,316-vote margin. And The Associated Press agreed with Mr. Webb, declaring Mr. Allen the loser. A1 New Democratic Faces While much of the focus in the campaign was on the more moderate tendencies of Democratic contenders, the scope of Tuesday's Democratic surge makes for a more complex picture. P1 Challenger Wins in Montana Democrats picked up the fifth of six seats needed to win control of the Senate when the late counting of votes from the mining town of Butte, Mont., showed Jon Tester had unseated the three-term Republican incumbent, Conrad Burns. P5 New York Agenda on the Hill Senator Charles E. Schumer and New York's Congressional delegation suddenly find themselves a locus of power on Capitol Hill, after years of being on the outs in Washington. And for a state with a long wish list, the ascendant Democrats in the House and Senate are well positioned to deliver hundreds of millions of new dollars to New York. P1 NATIONAL A25-30 Veterans Await PlaceTo Find Eternal Rest The federal government is racing to keep pace with the death of America's warriors. Half of the country's 124 veterans cemeteries are closed to burials. More than 1,800 veterans die each day, with 12 percent choosing a military burial. A25 Neanderthals in Gene Pool Scientists have found new genetic evidence that they say may answer the longstanding question of whether modern humans and Neanderthals interbred when they co-existed thousands of years ago. The answer is: probably yes, though not often. A27 NEW YORK/REGION B1-7 S.U.V. Accident Kills Child A sport utility vehicle careered onto a sidewalk in Brooklyn, hitting a mother and her three children, killing the woman's 5-year-old son, the police said. The driver then continued for about a block until she was forced to stop by at least one other driver, they said. She was charged with criminally negligent homicide and leaving the scene of an accident. B1 No Subway Cell Contract Yet It has been nearly 10 months since the Metropolitan Transportation Authority received four bids from companies interested in bringing cellphone service to the New York subway system. But the agency has yet to announce a winner. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-16 Microsoft to Pay Vivendi Microsoft agreed to pay a percentage of sales of its new portable media player, the Zune, to Vivendi's Universal Music Group, according to executives briefed on the deal. docs.lead_paragraph: A $90 million supercomputer made for nuclear weapons simulation cannot yet be rivaled by a single PC chip for a serious video gamer. But the gap is closing quickly. Indeed, a new breed of consumer-oriented graphics chips have roughly the brute computing processing power of the world's fastest computing system of just seven years ago. And the latest advance came Wednesday when the Nvidia Corporation introduced its next-generation processor, capable of more than three trillion mathematical operations per second.

headline.main: New Nvidia Chip Steps Closer To Supercomputing in the PC

docs.abstract: Nvidia Corporation introduces next-generation processor capable of more than three trillion mathematical operations per second; takes lead in technology race against rival ATI Technologies; development revives industry that has complained in recent years that it was running out of new ideas for gaining computing speed; both companies are working on new computer chip technologies expected to revolutionize computing; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Nvidia introduced its next-generation processor, capable of more than three trillion mathematical operations per second.

docs.lead_paragraph: Five time zones are reflected on the five clocks mounted above the counter at Fremont News: Tokyo, Paris, New York, Seattle and Fremont. The last is set five minutes behind Pacific Standard Time. ''Set your watch back five minutes,'' said Brad Beshaw, an assistant manager at the store, explaining why Fremont is slightly behind the times: ''Because Fremont's the center of the universe.''

headline.main: Time for a New Tenant In the Kingdom of Odd

docs.abstract: Fremont News, iconic newsstand in Seattle, will close on Nov 18; first opened in 1996 at time when newsstands across nation were struggling as sales of newspapers and magazines declined; John Hamel, who bought store in 2002, knew it was risky business, but forged ahead anyway; caters to hippies and other free-thinking segments of population; photos (M)
docs.snippet: At the end of next week, Fremont News, which has supplied newspapers, magazines, cigarettes and sundries to one of Seattle’s most deliberately distinctive neighborhoods for a decade, is closing for good.

docs.lead_paragraph: A blue streak sweeps through the region, and a victory in a hotly contested Senate race takes center stage, announcing a new breed of Democrat. Alaska Sarah Palin, a Republican and former mayor of an Anchorage suburb, became Alaska's first female governor, fighting off a comeback bid by Tony Knowles, a Democrat and former governor. Ms. Palin, a social and fiscal conservative who calls herself a ''hockey mom,'' rose to prominence by uncovering misconduct in the administration of Gov. Frank Murkowski, whom she later trounced in the Republican primary in August.

docs.lead_paragraph: Even before PlayStation 3, Sony's long-delayed new game console, goes on sale in Japan Saturday morning, it has already sold out -- in Japanese cyberspace. Across Tokyo, lines of young men were staying up overnight to be among the first to buy a console, but the frenzy began even before that. In October, the Japanese site of Amazon.com received advance orders for its entire first lot of game consoles in 18 minutes.

docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S a sign of how slow the government generally has been to take to the Internet that when the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission posts to a blog, it is seen as remarkable. The point of his post -- that the S.E.C. may be ready to allow companies to disclose material information to stockholders via the Internet -- was secondary (dealbook.blogs.nytimes.com).

docs.lead_paragraph: EVEN more than usual, it was a good week to be an investment banker. Certainly better than it was to be a floor specialist at the New York Stock Exchange or the editor of a major metropolitan newspaper. Pharmaceutical stocks fell on speculation that Democratic gains in this week's midterm elections would encourage legislative efforts to curb drug prices. Other shares also fell later in the week as weak consumer-confidence data revived concern about spending and economic growth. DEALS A GO-GO -- Companies that make everything from steaks to forklifts or provide services like hotel rooms and trucking were all on the market this week, in a mergers-and-acquisition bonanza among small and midsize companies.

headline.main: Jobs of Investment Bankers Appear to Be Safe

Their discussions led to the rough outline of a device that might do for portable music what the new Internet-enabled Xbox was poised to deliver to gaming: connected entertainment.

docs.lead_paragraph: Microsoft plans to unveil a technology industry alliance on Tuesday to make software from competing companies and partners work better together, company executives said. Bob Muglia, the Microsoft senior vice president who has led the company's so-called interoperability efforts for the last year, will announce details of the alliance in Barcelona, Spain, at an event for European software developers.

headline.main: Microsoft Aims to Improve Its 'Works Well With Others' Score

docs.abstract: Microsoft plans to unveil technology industry alliance to make software from competing companies and partners work better together; Microsoft senior vice president Bob Muglia will announce details of alliance in Barcelona, Spain, at event for European software developers; move is Microsoft's latest effort to move from being company that insists on advantages of its own products to one that can adapt when customers use other companies' goods; new Interop Vendor Alliance, which is being financed by Microsoft and is starting with 22 corporate members, will work publicly and privately to share information to solve common problems faced by customers and test real-world situations; Siemens, NEC, Business Objects, Software AG, Novell and Sun Microsystems are among alliance's members; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: GERMAN CORPORATE SHAKE-UPS -- The ousters of the heads of two marquee German companies -- Deutsche Telekom and Volkswagen -- show how treacherous corporate life is becoming in Germany, where bosses are caught between a new breed of aggressive investors and a set of stubborn old problems. Deutsche Telekom named René Obermann, above, to replace Kai-Uwe Ricke, who submitted his resignation Sunday after losing the confidence of big shareholders. [Page C1.] INTERNET VIA SATELLITE -- Companies like WildBlue and Hughes Network Systems, which provide Internet service via satellite, are filling one of the biggest gaps in the country's digital infrastructure. Roughly 15 million households cannot get broadband from their phone or cable provider because the companies have been slow to expand their high-speed networks in areas where there are not enough customers to generate an adequate profit. [C1.] BIG PAYDAY AT GOLDMAN -- Traders at Wall Street investment banks are priming themselves for another big bonus haul this year. And Raanan A. Agus, manager of one of Goldman Sachs' largest internal hedge funds will be in line for one of the firm's richer paydays. He is evidence that the real money on Wall Street is being made not by investment bankers cutting high-profile deals, but by anonymous traders making risky, bets with their firm's capital. [C1.] VALUE OF METS DEAL -- Experts in the realms of sports marketing, corporate identity and brand building offered sharply divergent views of the value of the huge deal that will name the new ballpark of the New York Mets for Citigroup. Under the deal, the new Mets stadium, scheduled to open in spring 2009, will be called Citi Field. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. [C5.] IT COULD HAVE BEEN WORSE -- The Mets stadium deal could have been worse. The new ballpark could have been named for some company overcharging in Iraq or a scandalized corporation or a geeky-sounding electronics firm that may or may not still exist when the gates open in 2009. Sports of the Times: George Vecsey [D1.] READY FOR BOARDING -- Airlines have been boarding passengers for decades, long enough, it would seem, to have figured out the best way to get people on and off a plane. But they haven't. Spurred by financial pressures and packed planes, airlines have come up with a wide variation of boarding techniques, from the simple back-to-front protocol to much more complicated strategies. The goal is to get planes back in the air faster. [C1.] BATTLE OVER HEALTH PLAN -- A legal battle over a plan to offer free or low-cost health care to all uninsured residents in San Francisco has been set in motion by a group of the city's most important and beloved constituents: restaurants. A culinary trade group with more than 800 members has sued the city, saying a central provision in the program violates federal employment law. [A14.] FEDERAL HEALTH PLAN -- The health insurance industry has proposed an expansion of Medicaid and new tax breaks with the goal of guaranteeing coverage for all children in three years and for virtually all adults within 10 years. New members of Congress, especially those elected on a pledge to help the uninsured, are likely to embrace many of the proposals, which provide a benchmark for debate on the issue. [A14.] MEN'S HEALTH -- In recent years, women's health has been a national priority. Pink ribbons warn of breast cancer. Pins shaped like red dresses raise awareness about heart disease. Yet statistics show that men are more likely than women to suffer an early death. Now some scientists are beginning to ask a question that in some circles might be considered politically incorrect: Is men's health getting short shrift? [F1.] VIETNAM TRADE VOTE -- Legislation to normalize trade relations with Vietnam was defeated in the House, four days before President Bush makes his first visit to the country. The measure failed to win the necessary two-thirds majority it needed to pass under a procedure adopted in an effort to rush it through with limited debate. The measure will be voted on again, possibly as early as today, under normal procedures which will require only a majority for passage. [C1.] MICROSOFT ALLIANCE -- Microsoft plans to unveil a technology industry alliance today to make software from competing companies and partners work better together. The move is latest effort by Microsoft to move from being a company that insists on the advantages of its own products to one that can adapt when customers use other companies' goods. The alliance will be announced in Barcelona, Spain, at an event for European software developers. [C3.] NEW TIVO FEATURES -- TiVo plans to introduce features that will allow people to use its digital video recorders to watch some video programming from the Internet on their televisions. Until now, TiVo has not been able to tap into the explosion of Web video Internet. The new features, to be announced today, are designed to change that. [C3.] LOSSES AT MEAT PROCESSOR -- Tyson Foods, the world's biggest meat processor, reported its third straight quarterly loss because of lower chicken and beef prices. Tyson said it would return to profit in 2007 and its stock price posted the biggest one-day gain since July. [C11.] HEDGE FUND SCRUTINY -- The Securities and Exchange Commission expects to file more lawsuits aimed at hedge funds accused of illegal trading and violating their clients' trust, the agency's chief enforcer said. [C9.]

docs.lead_paragraph: Empowered by a wave of venture capital, a hiring boom and pride in its homegrown billionaires, this city has decided it no longer needs a mediocre professional basketball team to feel good about itself. On Election Day, residents rebuffed their once-beloved Seattle SuperSonics, voting overwhelmingly for a ballot measure ending public subsidies for professional sports teams.

headline.main: As Sonics Pack to Leave Town, Seattle Shrugs

docs.abstract: Residents of Seattle, Wash, vote overwhelmingly for ballot measure ending public subsidies for professional sports teams, notably city's once-beloved Seattle SuperSonics; public sentiment turned against team when owner Howard Schultz warned that team would leave unless state provides $200 million to refurbish city-owned arena; photo (M)
docs.snippet: On Election Day, Seattle rebuffed its SuperSonics, voting to deny public subsidies for professional sports teams.

docs.lead_paragraph: TRYING TO REGULATE AN ARMY -- For years, companies including Avon Products, Herbalife and Amway have prospered by building armies of part-time sales representatives promoting insurance plans and anti-aging creams. Those representatives, in turn, are encouraged to recruit others and are promised that they will receive a portion of new enlistees' profits. The companies profit, at least in part, by collecting increased revenue and fees paid by new sales representatives. In April, citing hundreds of fraud investigations, the Federal Trade Commission proposed new rules for multilevel marketing companies and related businesses. [Page C1.] SHORTCUT TO FASHION -- For fashionistas in lower tax brackets, reproducing the latest hip look from Lindsay Lohan or Paris Hilton can mean endless clicking through online retail sites and hit-or-miss searches on Google or shopping engines like Shopping.com. Now a new search site, Like.com, offers a shortcut for the budget-minded. The site and its chief executive, Munjal Shah, left, rely on artificial-intelligence technology to search images on the Web, and serve up goods for sale that visually match items on a shopper's wish list. E-Commerce Report, Bob Tedeschi. [C4.] LIFE IN THE STUDIO -- In an era when producers, directors and popular actors are required to toe a stricter line, even Jerry Bruckheimer, the producer, is feeling the squeeze. His contribution to Disney cannot be underestimated. He has produced 17 films for the studio since 1991. They have brought in $5 billion. As part of a shift under Robert A. Iger, the new Disney chief executive, the studio pledged to make fewer films and focus on family-friendly movies that are marketable across all the company's businesses. That means Mr. Bruckheimer is now in the onscreen amusement park business. [C1.] MOVING ON AFTER XBOX -- The hoopla was still swelling around November's debut of the Xbox 360, when some on its development team began conceiving a new product. Tomorrow, after committing hundreds of millions of dollars, Microsoft is scheduled to release the result of that research: the Zune. At a glance, it looks like yet another aspiring iPod rival. But the Zune can do something that no other player can claim: it can locate other Zune players and wirelessly exchange content with a few touches of a big shiny button. [C1.] MUSIC FILLS THE AIR -- The upscale department store Nordstrom, which has taken a chance on up-and-coming designers, is now betting on a different set of rising stars: musicians. Beginning this holiday season, the retailer will develop and sell a collection of CDs that, over time, is expected to rival the one carried by Starbucks, its corporate neighbor in Seattle. [C11.] TAKING A NEW PATH -- Two big advertisers known for following traditional ways of marketing products are expanding their efforts to become a little less conventional. Both, coincidentally, share the same creative and media agencies, which are also trying to demonstrate their eagerness to explore the brave world of new media. The advertisers are the General Electric Company and the Pepsi-Cola North America unit of PepsiCo. The agencies are both part of the Omnicom Group: BBDO Worldwide in New York for the creative parts of the campaigns and OMD for the media elements. Everyone on Madison Avenue ''is looking to push the envelope, find what is going to be the next big thing,'' said Jennifer Gordineer, group director for national investment on the PepsiCo account at OMD. Advertising, Stuart Elliott. [C8.] GETTING A SECOND CHANCE -- Even adults, it seems, are getting a little sick of their childhoods, long after everyone else has. So TV Land, the network best-known for reruns of ''The Andy Griffith Show,'' is unveiling programming to appeal to what the network sees as one of the next obsessions for baby boomers: optimism about having second careers and changing lifestyles. Having recently produced reality shows with Farrah Fawcett and Mr. T, the network, which is owned by Viacom, is now turning its cameras on George Foreman, the former heavyweight boxing champion-turned-grill purveyor. [C10.] FINANCING FOR ETHANOL -- The Mascoma Corporation, a company that is trying to produce ethanol from nontraditional sources, has received $30 million from a group of prominent venture capital investors. The investment, which is led by General Catalyst Partners, and includes Khosla Ventures, Flagship Ventures, Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers and others, is the latest in a string of venture capital financings of alternative energy companies. Khosla and Flagship invested $9 million in Mascoma earlier this year. [C4.]

docs.lead_paragraph: For the second time in a generation, education officials are rethinking the teaching of math in American schools. The changes are being driven by students' lagging performance on international tests and mathematicians' warnings that more than a decade of so-called reform math -- critics call it fuzzy math -- has crippled students with its de-emphasizing of basic drills and memorization in favor of allowing children to find their own ways to solve problems.

headline.main: As Math Scores Lag, a New Push for the Basics

docs.abstract: American education officials are rethinking math teaching for second time in generation, pushed by students' lagging performance on international tests and warnings that reform math, which critics call 'fuzzy' math, has crippled learning by de-emphasizing basic drills and memorization in favor of allowing children to find own ways to solve problems; parental unease is also prompting many families to pay for private tutoring; National Council of Teachers of Mathematics, which influenced generation of change after 1989, now recommends tighter focus on basic skills and end to state requirements that schools teach dozens of math topics in each grade; new report calls for curriculum centering on 'quick recall' of multiplication and division, area of two-dimensional shapes and understanding of decimals; Washington, Utah and Florida area among states re-examining standards; grass-roots groups in cities agitate for return to basics, citing California's gains since it turned away from reform math; New York City says its curriculum covers both approaches; parents in Washington State strongly criticize teaching; only 51 percent of tenth-graders passed state tests in Sept, far fewer than were proficient in reading or writing; Prof Virginia Warfield notes that in Asia, where children test much higher, it is assumed that everyone learns math, and parents will help; photos (M)
docs.snippet: For the second time in a generation, education officials are rethinking the teaching of math in American schools.

docs.lead_paragraph: THIS year, as never before, the line between philanthropy and business is blurring. A new generation of philanthropists has stepped forward, for the most part young billionaires who have reaped the benefits of capitalism and believe that it can be applied in the service of charity. They are ''philanthropreneurs,'' driven to do good and have their profit, too. Among them are eBay's founder, Pierre Omidyar, who wants to use investment capital as well as donations to expand the microloan industry, and Stephen M. Case, the co-founder of America Online, who is investing $250 million in companies that help consumers gain control of their health care.

headline.main: What's Wrong With Profit?

docs.abstract: New generation of young billionaires who have reaped benefits of capitalism and believe that it can be applied in service of charity, is blurring line between business and philanthropy; approach of so-called philanthropreneurs reflects culture of business that brought them wealth: information technology with its ethos that everyone should have access to information; idea of hybrid philanthropy is upsetting long-held conventions; new philanthropists reject earlier models as ineffective and argue that in some cases only speed of capitalism is fast enough to meet needs; experts in philanthropy are unimpressed with newer models; profiles of Jeffrey S Skoll, Stephen M Case, Pierre Omidyar and Sir Richard Branson; photos (special section, Giving) (M)
docs.snippet: A new generation of “philanthropreneurs” has stepped forward, driven to do good and have their profit, too.

docs.lead_paragraph: MICROSOFT is offering free software -- two new easy-to-use programs -- to small businesses. Both are full-featured programs that should save business owners time and prove valuable in developing their companies. Microsoft Office Accounting Express 2007 is financial management software intended for small and home-based businesses. It consists of desktop software that can be downloaded as well as seven integrated online services for selling products online, sending invoices and receiving payments electronically, processing payroll, running credit reports, collaborating with an accountant and more.

docs.lead_paragraph: Bored with the same family photos on the fridge every day? Digital picture frames let you create slide shows of your loved ones that rotate through the frame's L.C.D. screen. Getting those pictures into the frame generally requires a direct connection to a computer, or the insertion of a flash memory card filled with photos. A new model from a British company called A Living Picture untethers the frame from all physical storage media, letting you download pictures to the frame over a Wi-Fi connection, wherever it sits in the house.

headline.main: The Picture Frame Goes Totally Tech, and No Wires

docs.lead_paragraph: The European Commission has threatened Microsoft with daily fines of 3 million euros ($5.7 million) if it does not provide certain information that would allow rival software developers to make their programs work smoothly with Windows. The order to reveal the documentation, released in a statement Wednesday by the commission, was part of a March 2004 antitrust ruling. It was the latest in a string of missed deadlines over the last two years imposed in an effort to get Microsoft to license technical information on its Windows operating system to rivals.

headline.main: Europe Warns Microsoft Over Compliance

docs.abstract: European Commission threatens Microsoft with daily fines of 3 million euros ($5.7 million) if it does not provide information allowing rival software developers to make programs work with Windows; Microsoft says it is 'committed to full compliance' with 2004 antitrust ruling (M)
docs.snippet: The European Commission threatened Microsoft with daily fines if it does not allow rivals to make their programs work with Windows.

docs.lead_paragraph: For those who believe that baseball is several hours of tedium punctuated by a few minutes of action, a new software package allows you to save time by cutting out the boring stretches. MagicSports 3 from CyberLink analyzes the action of a baseball game that has been recorded on a Windows-based PC with a TV tuner card, removing the commercials, the lineup changes and the foul balls. The interesting bits are arranged at the bottom of the screen as a series of thumbnails, labeled according to their excitement level. A strikeout gets one star, while a home run earns three. You can burn clips onto a DVD highlights reel.

headline.main: Condensed Baseball: Runs Without the Drips and Errors

docs.abstract: Condensed Baseball: Runs Without the Drip
docs.snippet: A new software package removes the commercials, the lineup changes and the foul balls of a baseball game.

MetroFi announced late Tuesday that it would introduce the Wi-Fi service in Pioneer Courthouse Square, a popular gathering place in downtown Portland, by the end of the year and expand it to the rest of the city within two years.

docs.lead_paragraph: THIS week Microsoft introduced Zune, its answer to Apple Computer's mighty pairing of the iPod portable media player and the iTunes music and video store. Though Zune offers a new choice for customers, it also highlights how restrictive such choices can be. With Zune, Microsoft follows the Apple strategy of linking a player and a download service. The Zune Marketplace, Microsoft's media store, offers two million songs, but they play on just one hand-held device. ''Zune calls attention to the conundrum that consumers don't like, which is being locked in to a retailer by virtue of what hardware you buy,'' said David Packman, chief executive of the online store eMusic.

headline.main: Why Can't All the Music Players Just Get Along?

docs.abstract: Basics column discusses competing music players and digital rights management standards from companies like Apple, Microsoft and Rhapsody that limit choices for consumers due to closed systems; offers tips on choosing best device and service; calls for universal format; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Restrictive hardware and convoluted rights management crimp consumer choices.

docs.lead_paragraph: Sony's new PlayStation 3 cannot play some of the games designed for previous generations of the popular console, the latest misstep for the company as it faces off in a crucial three-way war with Nintendo and Microsoft. Sony, which has fallen behind in crucial products like flat-panel TVs and digital music players, badly needs a best seller in the PlayStation 3. The console went on sale here to hordes of eager fans over the weekend, ahead of its release on Friday in the United States.

headline.main: PlayStation 3 Unable to Play Some of Sony's Earlier Games

docs.lead_paragraph: The Small Business Administration announced new rules yesterday intended to help small businesses obtain more federal contracts and to assure that contracts set aside for small businesses are not going to larger companies. The new rules will require small businesses to recertify their size when they are purchased by or merged with a larger business, or at the end of the five-year point of a contract.

docs.lead_paragraph: A coalition of business and education groups is making a renewed push to persuade Congress to raise the number of skilled foreign workers allowed into the United States this year. The coalition, which calls itself Compete America and whose members are drawn heavily from the technology industry, sent a letter to every member of Congress on Monday calling for an increase in both the number of so-called H-1B visas, which are used by skilled immigrants and the number of employment-based green cards given to foreign workers.

docs.lead_paragraph: A 210-foot construction crane collapsed and struck three buildings, killing a 31-year-old man inside a top floor apartment that was crushed, the authorities said. The crane was working on a vacant office building in downtown Bellevue, a Seattle suburb, when it toppled on Thursday night, Lt. Bruce Kroon of the Fire Department said. The operator suffered minor injuries but was able to pull himself out of the cage, which was 20 to 30 feet above the ground, Lieutenant Kroon said. The King County medical examiner's office identified the man who died as Matthew Ammon, an employee of Microsoft. The cause of the accident was not known. The crane is owned by the Morrow Equipment Company of Salem, Ore., KING-TV reported. E-mail and telephone messages to the company were not returned.

docs.lead_paragraph: MERGER activity was on the boil this week. A major airline that is itself the product of a recent merger offered to buy a competitor, a move that would reduce the number of airline seats and help carriers avoid savage fare wars. At the same time, some cash-flush private-equity funds independently swooped down on a major radio broadcaster and a big publisher. Retailers posted encouraging profits for the third quarter and consumer spending statistics suggest shoppers are eager to buy as the holiday shopping season is about to open. Robust discounting, however, may result in a disappointing fourth quarter. TAKING A FLIER -- Having been rejected twice in private, US Airways went public with a hostile takeover bid for Delta Air Lines, offering to buy the much-larger airline out of bankruptcy protection for $8 billion in cash and stock.

headline.main: Before the Holidays, a Passion for Mergers

docs.lead_paragraph: Everyone seems to have a theory about why Yahoo! is struggling. Google, its rival and a darling of the investment world, is often cited as a major cause of the Web portal's woes. Yahoo senior vice president Brad Garlinghouse recently compared his company's predicament to a popular condiment in a four-page internal memo dubbed "The Peanut Butter Manifesto." Whatever the cause, The New York Times wrote Monday that there is an emerging consensus about one thing: If Yahoo remains an underachiever, it could be a candidate for takeover.

docs.lead_paragraph: MOSTLY GRAVY -- It is a holiday week, so there is fairly little on the schedule. Markets, of course, will be closed Thursday in observance of Thanksgiving. The bond market will close early on Wednesday. The only economic reports due out are the leading economic indicators for October, on Monday, and the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index, on Wednesday. COMPETITIVE PRESSURES -- On Monday, Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. (above) will speak on the competitiveness of the capital markets in the United States before the Economic Club of New York. The subject has become a contentious one, with corporate America clamoring for relief from what it says are the more onerous governance and auditing requirements of the 2002 Sarbanes-Oxley Act. The burdens of regulatory compliance have been blamed for the reluctance of foreign companies to list their securities on American markets. BUY-BUY -- The day after Thanksgiving is Black Friday, the traditional starting gun for the Christmas and Hanukkah shopping orgy. Although many stores have historically held huge promotional events pegged to the annual ritual, this year some retailers started early. Wal-Mart Stores, for instance, introduced some online deals in October and said it would cut more prices at its online store on Thanksgiving Day. Sony's PlayStation 3 may be hard to come by, but there are other options for people who crave new (and highly publicized) technology gadgets: Microsoft has started selling its Zune portable music player, and Nintendo just introduced its Wii game console. ANNOUNCE, THEN FEAST -- Although it will be a bountiful week at dinner tables across America, it will be a thin week for corporate earnings. Among the relatively few companies reporting will be: Campbell Soup, Lowe's Companies, Medtronic, Nordstrom and Phillips-Van Heusen (Monday); Borders Group, Eaton Vance and J. Crew Group (Tuesday); and Hormel Foods (Wednesday).

headline.main: LOOKING AHEAD

docs.lead_paragraph: A consortium of seven newspaper chains representing 176 daily papers across the country is announcing a broad partnership with Yahoo to share content, advertising and technology, another sign that the wary newspaper business is increasingly willing to shake hands with the technology companies they once saw as a threat. In the first phase of the deal, the newspaper companies will begin posting their employment classified ads on Yahoo's classified jobs site, HotJobs, and start using HotJobs technology to run their own online career ads.

headline.main: 176 Newspapers to Form a Partnership With Yahoo

docs.lead_paragraph: Howard Stringer, you have a problem. Your company's new video game system just isn't that great. Ever since Mr. Stringer took the helm last year at Sony, the struggling if still formidable electronics giant, the world has been hearing about how the coming PlayStation 3 would save the company, or at least revitalize it. Even after Microsoft took the lead in the video-game wars a year ago with its innovative and powerful Xbox 360, Sony blithely insisted that the PS3 would leapfrog all competition to deliver an unsurpassed level of fun. Put bluntly, Sony has failed to deliver on that promise.

headline.main: A Weekend Full of Quality Time With PlayStation 3

docs.abstract: PlayStation 3 video game console fails to live up to expectations set by head of Sony Howard Stringer; Stringer claimed that new system would beat out all competition and essentially save struggling company; while console is certainly most powerful around, it fails to provide overall entertainment experience of Xbox 360; photos (M)
docs.snippet: The PlayStation 3 system is surprisingly clunky to use and simply does not provide many basic functions that users have come to expect.

docs.lead_paragraph: IN mid-October, Yahoo, the world's biggest Internet portal, reported a sharp profit skid and warned of a further growth slowdown in two major lines of business -- a performance that its unusually contrite chief executive said had failed to fully exploit the company's strengths. That was enough for Scott W. Devitt, an analyst based in Manassas, Va., who covers Yahoo for Stifel, Nicolaus & Company, the investment banking firm. Three days later, Mr. Devitt downgraded Yahoo shares -- which at the turn of the century traded above $100 and were then about $23 -- to a hold from a buy. Fidelity Investments has also soured on the stock, but declined to say why it sold 55.6 million Yahoo shares between midyear and Oct. 31.

headline.main: Sunny and Gloomy Signs at a Web Crossroads

docs.snippet: The main problem is that Yahoo has not been nearly as good as Google at reaping profits from the huge volume of search traffic it attracts.

docs.lead_paragraph: GOOGLE, STILL FEELING LUCKY -- Google's shares closed up $14.60 at $509.65, rising past the $500 mark for the first time, not bad for a company that was forced to reduce its initial share price to $85 barely two years ago because of lackluster demand. And an analyst who once recommended selling at $137 is among those predicting that it will rise to $600 within a year. [Page C1.] A LINE IN THE SAND -- Rupert Murdoch has pushed the boundaries throughout his career, usually without contrition. But the media billionaire's decision to cancel a TV and book project featuring O. J. Simpson by subsidiaries of the News Corporation was a rare demonstration that even Mr. Murdoch has his limits. [C1.] RIGHTS TO SIMPSON BOOK SOUGHT -- Seeking to prevent a canceled book and television interview with O. J. Simpson from ever becoming public, the family of Ronald L. Goldman, who was murdered along with Nicole Brown Simpson in 1994, has asked the News Corporation to turn over the rights to the material. [C5.] INVESTORS SHOW FAITH IN DELL -- Dell reported another quarter of slow revenue growth and falling profits, compared to year-earlier results. But investors looked at the marked improvement from the previous quarter as a sign of a turnaround and pushed the company's stock up in after-hours trading. [C1.] SENATOR AT THE CROSSROADS -- As Senator Christopher Dodd prepares to take over the leadership of the Senate Banking Committee while also considering a run for the presidency, lobbyists and lawmakers are all asking the same question. Will he be a populist champion for the middle class or will he advance the causes of corporate patrons? [C1.] ASIAN GIANTS SEEK CLOSER TIES -- India and China established a 10-point strategy to strengthen economic relations as President Hu Jintao of China, left, started a four-day visit to India. As he and Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India came face to face, there was evidence that they were trying to define the Asian version of globalization. [C2.] SHORT-LIVED SOFTWARE CEASE-FIRE -- Less than three weeks after they reached an accord hailed as proof that open source and proprietary software companies could work together, Novell and Microsoft executives are bickering in public. [C4.] POTATO TODAY, GONE TOMORROW -- The United States Potato Board is joining the ranks of marketers using a technique known as pop-up retailing, opening a temporary store that consumers can visit for a short time. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C4.] LENS CLEANER RECALLED -- Advanced Medical Optics has recalled 2.9 million bottles of Complete MoisturePlus contact lens solution after harmful bacteria were found in some units sold in Japan. The company's shares fell 8.9 percent, and the company issued lowered forecasts for sales and earnings through 2007. The voluntary recall is a precaution against eye infections caused by water-borne bacteria that infiltrated a plant in China; no problems have been reported in the United States. [C6.] COMCAST AND DISNEY IN DEAL -- The Comcast Corporation and the Walt Disney Company have signed a multibillion-dollar distribution deal that allows the cable operator to distribute Disney content through its video-on-demand service. [C10.] G.M. SCUTTLES SATURN MINIVAN -- General Motors confirmed that it had decided not to build a Saturn minivan that was tentatively planned for production at its Spring Hill, Tenn., plant, but the company said that it would find a new vehicle for workers there to build. Union leaders said they feared the plant, where the first Saturn was built, would close. [C4.] PENTAGON SEEKS SUPERCOMPUTER -- The Pentagon awarded almost $500 million in contracts to I.B.M. and Cray Inc. to design a supercomputer several times as fast as today's most powerful systems. [C8.] AVIATION COMPANY RISES IN DEBUT -- Shares of Spirit AeroSystems Holdings, a unit of Onex, the Canadian leveraged buyout company, rose 12 percent in their first day of trading in New York yesterday. Onex formed Spirit in June 2005 after acquiring Boeing's aircraft component factories in Wichita, Kan., and Tulsa and McAlester, Okla. Spirit stock opened at $26 and ended the day's trading at $29 a share. [C8] STOCKS RISE WITH OIL PRICES -- Stocks resumed their November advance yesterday after an increase in oil prices lifted the Exxon Mobil Corporation, the world's biggest energy company, and shares of Google surpassed $500 for the first time. [C8.] Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. The accounting firm KPMG asked a federal appeals panel to rule that a district judge could not compel the firm to pay the legal fees of former executives facing criminal charges in a tax-shelter fraud investigation. (DOW JONES) The bookstore operator Borders Group said that its third-quarter loss widened as sales edged down. The company reported a loss of $39.1 million, or 64 cents a share, for the quarter that ended Oct. 28 compared with a loss of $14.1 million, or 20 cents in the period a year ago. (AP) Higher prices for farm and lawn-care equipment helped Deere & Company increase its fourth-quarter profit by 19 percent, the company said Tuesday. The share price rose sharply, even as the company warned of a sales slowdown. (AP) EarthLink, the Internet access provider, said that its chief executive, Garry Betty, would take a medical leave to fight cancer. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

docs.lead_paragraph: WITH the recent Senate passage of the Combating Autism Act, the House is now poised to approve landmark legislation to help scientists understand the causes and characteristics of autism -- a spectrum of neurological disorders affecting more than 1 in 200 children in the United States. If the House does as we hope and passes the act, the National Institutes of Health and related health research agencies will finally begin to devote the magnitude of resources -- nearly $200 million a year -- commensurate with the severity and prevalence of this terribly devastating set of conditions. The research emphasis of the act is appropriate, given how little is still known about the causes and the physiology of autism spectrum disorders, as well as the means by which medical treatments can reduce autism's severity if applied early enough. Basic questions like whether the frequency of childhood vaccines today contributes to autism are still unresolved.

headline.main: Studying Autism Isn't Enough

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Cathryn Garland and Michael O'Hanlon, parents of autistic child, urges House to approve Senate-passed Combating Autism Act, landmark legislation that will help scientists understand complex spectrum of neurological disorders that afect more than one in 200 American children (M)
docs.snippet: We as a nation must begin to focus seriously on treating those children who are already afflicted with autism. At present, we are failing miserably to do so.

docs.lead_paragraph: Judging by sheer silicon horsepower, the Nintendo Wii is the least powerful of the new generation of video game systems. But for many people it will be the most fun, and that's what really matters. Unlike Microsoft's Xbox 360 and Sony's PlayStation 3, the Wii does not produce eyepopping high-definition graphics. Unlike its brawnier and more expensive brethren, it does not feature an extensive online service built around multiplayer gaming. Unlike the 360 and the PS3, the Wii isn't trying to be the most advanced digital entertainment system out there. Instead, the Wii (pronounced ''we,'' not ''why'') is about rescuing gaming from the clutches of the hard-core young male demographic that has dominated the industry's thinking for years. It is about making video games accessible again by providing a simple, intuitive, relatively inexpensive entertainment experience that an entire family can actually enjoy together.

headline.main: Getting Everybody Back in the Game

docs.snippet: The Nintendo Wii may be the least powerful of the new generation of video game systems, but for many it will be the most fun, and that’s what really matters.

docs.lead_paragraph: When the iPod Won't Charge Q. I left my iPod plugged into my computer all night and it didn't get fully charged. Why is this? A. Several things can affect the iPod's ability to charge its battery while plugged into your PC or Mac. For starters, most computers won't charge the iPod if they go to sleep after a period of inactivity, so check your system settings for sleep or hibernation. Low-powered U.S.B. ports, like the kind found on keyboards, may also fail to charge the iPod.

The agreement was made with the Belgian copyright groups Sofam, representing about 3,700 photographers, and Scam, on behalf of journalists. In September, Google lost a copyright suit initially filed by Copiepresse, a group representing French- and German-language newspapers in Belgium. That case is being reheard, but the company has removed links to 17 papers from its Google News page.

docs.lead_paragraph: LIKE Lake Wobegon, Garrison Keillor's fictitious Minnesota town where all the children are above average, executive compensation practices often assume that corporate managers are equally superlative. When shareholders question lush pay, they are invariably met with a laundry list of reasons that businesses use to justify such packages. Among that data, no item is more crucial than the ''peer group,'' a collection of companies that corporations measure themselves against when calculating compensation. But according to a handful of pay experts who are privy to the design of pay practices at the nation's largest corporations, many of these peer groups are populated with companies that are anything but comparable. They also say corporate managers themselves -- who have an interest in higher pay -- are selecting which companies make it into a peer group. And because these companies are often inappropriate for comparison purposes, their use has helped inflate executive pay in recent years.

headline.main: GILDED PAYCHECKS: Group Think; Peer Pressure: Inflating Executive Pay

docs.abstract: Corporations increasingly use collection of companies known as peer groups to determine executive pay; details are sketchy as to how businesses make up groups and if they are true representations of equals or just way to increase salaries; photos; graph (M)
docs.snippet: As is true with much about executive pay, details about exactly how peer groups are compiled have been kept under wraps.

docs.lead_paragraph: The job market for Indian college graduates is split sharply in two. With a robust handshake, a placeless accent and a confident walk, you can get a $300-a-month job with Citibank or Microsoft. With a limp handshake and a thick accent, you might peddle credit cards door to door for $2 a day. India was once divided chiefly by caste. Today, new criteria are creating a different divide: skills. Those with marketable skills are sought by a new economy of call centers and software houses; those without are ensnared in old, drudgelike jobs.

headline.main: A College Education Without Job Prospects

docs.abstract: Article on sharp dividing line between two kinds of universities across India and impact divide is having on college students' future job prospects; few thousand students who graduate each year from top academies garner jobs on Wall Street, Silicon Valley and at leading local employers while most of 11 million students in India's 18,000 colleges and universities receive starkly inferior training, heavy on obedience and light on useful skills; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Most of the 11 million students in India’s 18,000 colleges and universities receive starkly inferior training, heavy on obedience and light on useful job skills.

docs.lead_paragraph: When computer industry executives heard about a plan to build a $100 laptop for the developing world's children, they generally ridiculed the idea. docs.lead_paragraph: Small Business Fighting Big Spam Q. Do you have any suggestions for individuals and small businesses to combat spam? A. Small businesses can have just as much unsolicited junk mail clogging their mail servers as do larger corporations, but often lack the human and software resources of the bigger companies to fight it as effectively. But there are some options for fighting back. Many Internet service providers or companies like Yahoo that host small-business Web sites and mail servers offer spam filtering at the server level, so you may want to check with your I.S.P. to see what's available. Providers like America Online and EarthLink already filter spam for individual e-mail accounts. If you are still getting a lot of junk in your mailbox, you might try adjusting the filter settings; check your service's Help guide for instructions.

docs.lead_paragraph: Most of the biggest, most highly anticipated video games of the year come out in the few months preceding Christmas. So why was I so bored? Big-budget games are coming out to rave reviews and big sales, but when I played them I thought, I've played these already. Happily, the folks at Nintendo decided to do something about the stagnancy in game design. The new Nintendo Wii game console challenges designers to think outside the box with the inclusion of a special motion-sensitive game controller that looks like a television remote and allows you to play games in a remarkably intuitive fashion.

docs.lead_paragraph: Entrepreneurs have plenty of things to keep them awake at night worrying: payroll, inventory, pricing, competition. For Jere Smith and her husband, Don Lueders, the main thing is health insurance. Many small-business owners struggle with the high cost of health insurance, but it is even more critical for entrepreneurs with ventures less than five years old, the time when a business tries to build its clientele and profits. And because many start-ups typically include few employees, if any, they cannot always take advantage of discounted insurance rates that groups enjoy.

headline.main: Health Care at a Premium

docs.abstract: High cost of health insurance premiums is having adverse impact on many small-businesses, particularly those less than five years old; Kaiser Family Foundation phone survey of 2,122 companies has found that premiums for small companies rose average of 8.8 percent this year, compared with 7 percent rise for larger companies that have more than 200 employees; entrepreneurs, including Jere Smith and husband Don Lueders, who own transmission franchise, comment; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Experts say rising health insurance costs are causing problems for start-ups and keeping some would-be entrepreneurs from starting businesses.

For Mr. Lanzone, chief executive of Ask.com, the prop is a reminder of what the Internet search company he runs has ceased to be.
